TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member, who was shouting, to proceed to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall. Was thinking that perhaps our flight was scheduled to park in a further lot due to multiple flights arriving around the same time. Personally, I wasnt expecting to go through the hassle of having to transit from the plane to the arrival hall, taking into consideration that this was a direct flight. Anyway, still went with the flow and follow those in front since we are told to.... This information could easily be missed if people are talking or focused on finding the nearest toilet. Although the airport was large and packed with lots of shops and eateries, there are areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving/departure passengers. Would suggest the following improvements: * Rather than having a staff member shouting/giving instructions, can consider placing clear, large signage on both sides of the walkway as passengers disembark. * Provide more readily available information upon flight arrival / departure. * Consider adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Clear directional signs and information would make a big difference for first-time visitors like myself and would save a lot of time especially when there are so many incoming/outgoing flights day to day..... The signage for the bus transfer was unclear, and it took approximately 4-5 minutes to find the waiting point to queue for the feeder bus to the arrival hall. Upon arriving at the arrival hall, it was another 2-minute walk to reach immigration. The area was extremely crowded, with queues of 2-3 lines in a row, resulting in an hour-long wait to clear immigration. The process was very disorganized and messy, with no one managing the human traffic, possibly due to a shortage of manpower. Although the officers were friendly and efficient in clearing the queue, it would be beneficial to have crowd control/security to guide and manage the flow of passengers. Locating the correct baggage belt after clearing immigration was another challenge. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts, requiring passengers to walk near the belt to check the monitor screen. This was frustrating, especially with different groups of people surrounding the area, some looking for directions, some waiting for friends, and others searching for the right belt. We eventually found our luggage placed not far away from the luggage belt area near the exit, with a sign displaying the SQ Airlines logo on the floor. Many unclaimed bags from our flight were present, as most passengers were still stuck in immigration. The entire process, from disembarking the plane to retrieving our luggage outside the baggage claim area, was challenging. I thought we were only required to transit to the arrival hall as a one-time occurrence. However, on our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient. As a tourist, the airport gives the first impression for passengers, and its organization is crucial. I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements

TEXT: One of the worst airport experiences Ive ever had. While the airport is spacious, the design is extremely confusing. Each level has two separate sides, and if you accidentally end up on the wrong one, you have to go back up and re-enter from another point theres no direct way to cross over. The terminals are connected by trains, but shockingly, youre charged 2 MYR per person just to use them! Shuttle buses are available, but only from specific areas that take at least 30 minutes of walking to reach, with no clear guidance. There are no proper information desks, and youre left to ask random staff who often give vague or conflicting directions. To make matters worse, baggage trolley staff were communicating using loud whistles it was chaotic and very unpleasant. The AirAsia terminal (2) was particularly bad and felt extremely disorganized. This experience alone is enough to make me reconsider visiting Malaysia again just to avoid going through this airport.

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers. These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member to go to C15 for a transfer to the arrival hall. Rather having a staff to shout ,wouldn't it be better to put up clear large signage at both side of the walk way while we disembark? The signage for this bus transfer was also unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus. Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldnt it be better to have basic international standard too? Situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall. The area was extremely crowded,people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration. Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic which leads to all these mess. After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for. The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when yiu have different groups of people surrounding the area....some was waiting for their friends while some was was looking for the right belt for their luggage. Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right. We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the Singapore Airlines logo on the floor. Quite a handful of luggage was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight were still stuck in immigration. Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt. Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage much of which was in Malay. This can be rather challenging, especially after a series of such "events" we went through. We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter, who knows we must go through the same things going back. On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.We have to endure our thirst till our flight take off. As a tourist, I dont enjoy it if I have to go through so much hassle. This was one of a kind of experience i wasn't expecting from KLIA... Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.

TEXT: The airport looks very fancy and all - at least Terminal 1. It is very unorganized though. We arrived extremely late from our first flight (thank you batik air) and only had 15-20min items to get our connecting flight. Normally airports would provide a shuttle services, picking you from a gate to bring you to your connecting flight in time. This was not the case here, we were only told the gate number of our connecting flight, which after running to for 10min, turned out to be the wrong gate. So instead we had to take the bus to another terminal, which obviously did not give us enough time to catch our flight, so we were stuck in KL for 1 night. Additionally it is ridiculous, that there is no smoking area in the entirety of terminal 1. So if you are stuck here for a while you have to go all the way to terminal 2, into one of the most disgusting smoking rooms Ive witnessed in my life (no ventilation at all, might as well just walk in and breath twice and youve already passively smoked a carton of cigarettes). Really disappointing for such a modern (only t1) and large airport.

Normally airport would provide shuttle service , pick gate bring connect flight time . This case , tell gate number connect flight , run 10min , turn wrong gate . So instead take bus another terminal , obviously give u enough time catch flight , stick KL 1 night . Additionally ridiculous , smoke area entirety terminal 1 . So stick go way terminal 2 , one disgusting smoking room Ive witness life ( ventilation , might well walk breath twice youve already passively smoke carton cigarette ) . Really disappoint modern ( t1 ) large .

TEXT: Arriving: Immigration for arrivals took too long! The officers works so slowly and the poor internet connection in this area is not helping either. It took us long enough to complete immigration to the point that our bags were no longer in the conveyor belt/shown on screen. Pick up location of ride hailing (Grab) was easy at Level 1. Departure: Check in counters are spread out making it not too crowded/congested. Immigration for departure is quicker and easier. However, there's a security screening for customs departure that was separated with at-gate security check. I would say this is very inefficient as you need to check your bags twice and once you have cleared security you practically cannot go out to the retail area. In addition, the post-security gate is a nightmare with neither water stations nor proper toilet! There seems to be no signs of priority boarding based on group but rather by seats (not sure if this is an MH or KLIA problem). Retail space is decent with great tax-free goods options and decent restaurant selections. One thing to appreciate: the toilets (in retail & public) areas are clean and equipped with jet showers.

It take u long enough complete immigration point bag longer conveyor belt/shown screen . Pick location ride hailing ( Grab ) easy Level 1 . Departure : Check counter spread make crowded/congested . Immigration departure quick easy . However , 's security screening custom departure separate at-gate security check . I would say inefficient need check bag twice clear security practically go retail area . In addition , post-security gate nightmare neither water station proper toilet ! There seem sign priority board base group rather seat ( sure MH KLIA problem ) . Retail space decent great tax-free good option decent restaurant selection . One thing appreciate : toilet ( retail & public ) area clean equip jet shower .

TEXT: Exhausting.. you need to have atleast a year of airport work experience to just transit through this airport. It took nearly 2 hrs from landing to sitting down at our gate. So much is automated and so few staff members to help. So many more hurdles to jump such as filling in an MDAC, yes, we were asked to fill it in on-line at Siem Reap, but thought it couldn't possibly be for us as so many 'mandatory' boxes were irrelevant to us. However, at the airport, they insisted we filled it in with a bunch of false information, i.e. the address where we would be staying (had to put in an they address provided.. which was the airport's address) a waste of time, as we felt we could miss our connecting flight. We also had to create our own baggage tags, then TWO separate baggage screenings - so unnecessary. TEXT: I recently arrived at Kuala Lumpur International Airport from Perth and was very disappointed with the accessibility. There was only one working escalator and no functioning elevator or alternative staircase available. I found this experience stressful and embarrassing, and I will avoid this route in the future unless accessibility improves.

TEXT: Arrived at Kuala Lumpur in the late afternoon, and the queue at immigration was very long. We got in and waited about 15 minutes, when we left there were 2-3 times as many people, so they must have waited for over 30 minutes. There are not many officers. But the thing that annoyed the most, was the lack of transparency regarding the newly introduced MDAC that every foreigner needs to fill in. About 20% of the people in the queue wait for a long time, and then when coming to the immigration officer they did not fill in the MDAC and the foreigner is redirected to the back again to fill it in. It is a waste of time for people waiting, the immigration officers and for the people who did not fill it in. It is very simple, put some signage to be clear at the start of the queue. "Did you fill in your MDAC?". If not, fill it in first. I literally filled it in in 2 minutes while I was in the long queue. Sure, everyone needs to do their own research. But from a big airport like Kuala Lumpur, this is terrible organization and messes with people who have connecting flights.

But thing annoy , lack transparency regard newly introduce MDAC every foreigner need fill . About 20 % people queue wait long time , come immigration officer fill MDAC foreigner redirect back fill . It waste time people wait , immigration officer people fill . It simple , put signage clear start queue . `` Did fill MDAC ? '' . If , fill first . I literally fill 2 minute I long queue . Sure , everyone need research . But big like Kuala Lumpur , terrible organization mess people connect flight .

TEXT: I was assaulted by a female airport customer experience officer who attempted to physically restrain me without justification. When I demanded to file a police report, I was told I would have to go to Terminal 2something my Australian emergency passport did not permit. Despite my repeated requests, the airport police refused to take my report and instead escorted me to the immigration department. There, I was met by an aggressive and unprofessional immigration officer named Kamarudin. When I asked for his full name in writing, he refused and rudely pointed to his name badge, telling me to take a photo with my phone. The moment I did, he became enraged and began intimidating meeven going so far as to take photos of me and my passport on his personal phone. This was a blatant violation of privacy and professional conduct. **Malaysias airport authorities and immigration officers behaved in a disgusting, abusive, and unaccountable manner. Travelers beware: AVOID MALAYSIA at all costs!** **Legal Analysis** This conduct raises multiple violations under Malaysian law: 1. **Assault and Criminal Force (Penal Code Sections 350-352)** The staff member's actions in grabbing my arms and physically restraining me without consent constitutes criminal force under Section 350. Case precedent (PP v. Mohd Anuar bin Abdullah [1994] 2 MLJ 261) confirms that any intentional use of force without lawful justification meets this threshold. 2. **Wrongful Confinement (Penal Code Section 340)** The unlawful restriction of my movement within the clinic treatment room amounts to wrongful confinement. Malaysian jurisprudence establishes that detention without legal authority is punishable, particularly where no legitimate lien exists over the person. 3. **Official Misconduct** The behavior of Immigration Officer Kamarudin in: - Failing to properly address a criminal complaint - Intimidating a complainant - Improper use of personal devices to photograph sensitive documents May constitute offenses under Malaysia's official misconduct provisions. UPDATE: Malaysian Airport Management have promised a full investigation of this matter however no official response as of yet.

When I demand file police report , I tell I would go Terminal 2something Australian emergency passport permit . Despite repeated request , police refuse take report instead escort immigration department . There , I meet aggressive unprofessional immigration officer name Kamarudin . When I ask full name writing , refuse rudely point name badge , tell take photo phone . The moment I , become enraged begin intimidate meeven go far take photo passport personal phone . This blatant violation privacy professional conduct . * * Malaysias authority immigration officer behave disgusting , abusive , unaccountable manner . Travelers beware : AVOID MALAYSIA cost ! * * * * Legal Analysis * * This conduct raise multiple violation Malaysian law : 1 . * * Assault Criminal Force ( Penal Code Sections 350-352 ) * * The staff member 's action grab arm physically restrain without consent constitutes criminal force Section 350 . Case precedent ( PP v. Mohd Anuar bin Abdullah [ 1994 ] 2 MLJ 261 ) confirms intentional use force without lawful justification meet threshold . 2 . * * Wrongful Confinement ( Penal Code Section 340 ) * * The unlawful restriction movement within clinic treatment room amount wrongful confinement . Malaysian jurisprudence establishes detention without legal authority punishable , particularly legitimate lien exist person . 3 . * * Official Misconduct * * The behavior Immigration Officer Kamarudin : - Failing properly address criminal complaint - Intimidating complainant - Improper use personal device photograph sensitive document May constitute offense Malaysia 's official misconduct provision . UPDATE : Malaysian Airport Management promise full investigation matter however official response yet .

TEXT: Most staff at this airport have no sense of dealing with people and work randomly. When problems arise, they shout instead of helping, and there is no way to file a complaint. Malaysia is not Truly Asia as advertised, real change must start with the staff. This is also the only airport where you are subjected to security checks three times, and reaching the gate feels like a journey of confusion and hardship. The staff neither smile nor show willingness to help, often seeking to exploit and complicate matters. If you want Truly Asia, it is Thailand, with its genuine smiles and kindness. I hope not to return here again; learn from Thailand and Dubai how to treat people.

TEXT: What happened to KLIA? I loved this airport. It was clean, friendly, quick and easy to get through. But the past few times it was horrible: long lines, unfriendly and unhelpful staff, angry travelers, expensive food (yes, more expensive) and more. Toilets are overal dirty too. Travelers are also unfriendly and loud. Not KLIAs fault, but nobody seems to care. Cellphones everywhere playing all kind of videos, loud phone calls, and playing music that's just horrible. The rain forest thing seems a joke to me. Nice idea, but its advertised as if its huge. It's not, its small. Nice view through a window inside it, because it was closed and I have no idea if its normally open to enter. When I went through security it felt to easy, and it was. It seems gates have a second security point. No clear lines, no communication, and everyone is pushing and pulling to get through. Staff dont seem to care. I almost missed my flight because there were 4 lines for 1 gate and nobody knew who could go through. Add some clear lines or something. Two positive things: arriving is pretty simple and quick. And when leaving I know I will be in a plane at some point.

TEXT: One of the worst airport experiences Ive ever had. While the airport is spacious, the design is extremely confusing. Each level has two separate sides, and if you accidentally end up on the wrong one, you have to go back up and re-enter from another point theres no direct way to cross over. The terminals are connected by trains, but shockingly, youre charged 2 MYR per person just to use them! Shuttle buses are available, but only from specific areas that take at least 30 minutes of walking to reach, with no clear guidance. There are no proper information desks, and youre left to ask random staff who often give vague or conflicting directions. To make matters worse, baggage trolley staff were communicating using loud whistles it was chaotic and very unpleasant. The AirAsia terminal (2) was particularly bad and felt extremely disorganized. This experience alone is enough to make me reconsider visiting Malaysia again just to avoid going through this airport.

To make matter bad , baggage trolley staff communicate use loud whistle chaotic unpleasant . The AirAsia terminal ( 2 ) particularly bad felt extremely disorganize . This experience alone enough make reconsider visit Malaysia avoid go .

TEXT: We flew with Batik Air and had to go to Gate G8. After check-in, you go through passport control for international flights. Then there's a backpack check, where you have to put all your bags and backpacks through the scanner. Your body isn't scanned, though, so it's not a proper security check. After that, you're in the duty-free area and can walk to the gates. We bought some food and drinks to take with us onto the plane. Unfortunately, there was a proper security check before Gates G8 and G10, so we had to empty and dispose of all liquids there. After this point, you're in the waiting area and aren't given any drinks or food.

Your body n't scan , though , 's proper security check . After , 're duty-free area walk gate . We buy food drink take u onto plane . Unfortunately , proper security check Gates G8 G10 , empty dispose liquid . After point , 're wait area n't give drink food .

TEXT: Absolutely horrible check in process at Malaysia airport. I arrived at the aiport at 6 AM, 3 hours before my 9 AM flight, only to see a line of 500 people in front of me everyone checking in for Malaysia airlines flights at different times. Some people checking in for 11 AM flight and getting in the line. I had already done web check in, I had printed luggage tags and boarding pass, I just wanted to drop off my check in bag and go to my terminal for breakfast. But the whole process was organised so horribly that I was in the line for 1 hour only to check in my bag. Then another hour to reach my terminal and then 45 mins in line for boarding. I didnt get to have any breakfast or relax before my flight. Flight was delayed by 30+ mins on tarmac. Shame on Malaysia airlines and Malaysia airport for such terrible management. Next time I am going to buy Batik Air tickets.

But whole process organise horribly I line 1 hour check bag . Then another hour reach terminal 45 min line board . I didnt get breakfast relax flight . Flight delay 30+ min tarmac . Shame Malaysia airline Malaysia terrible management . Next time I go buy Batik Air ticket .

TEXT: First and Last Time! It's my first time in Malaysia, traveling from Abu Dhabi. As a UAE resident, I take pride in the excellent regulations we have. My wife and I have never encountered such treatment at any airport before, and we were shocked to learn that these items are considered "non-carryable" on flights, the things cost more than 500 AED, very disappointed, and will never come again worst experience ever. TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, "because it's too late now to buy tickets" (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid almost triple the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. And also, the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration! I had such a hard time to book the Grab taxi and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, in any airport that's when wifi is needed!! But here there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!! I've never had this much hastle and wasted time to manage to exit an airport, oh yeah, and the airport is so far away from the city it took us 90 minutes to reach the hotel (with zero traffic after midnight) knowing this, the designers still decided to add a mall to make your trip even slower! This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

Yes , literal mall every world 'd check transportation finally leave . After long flight , last thing anyone want drag maze store leave . It felt like cash grab , travel hub . We finally make relieve see Grab available ( use Thailand ) . But book ride , wait time 35 minute ! There huge , overcrowd Grab wait area screen show incoming car plate , clearly , demand way beyond could handle . Tired frustrate , give Grab , hop catch bus instead . But werent allow buy ticket exactly 12 AM , also list departure time bus , `` 's late buy ticket '' ( 15 minute ahead ) . We tell bus would leave even 12 . TEXT: A more than bad experience... I arrived at the airport at 7:00 AM, and went directly to wrap my large bag. There were only two people in front of me, but the wrapping took longer than expected. When I got to the baggage check-in counter, I found the queue very long, and my turn didn't come until 8:15 AM!!! The flight gate opened... When I finished, I didn't know where to go to find the gate, so I asked one of the employees, and her response was very... When she left, she started mocking me in front of the shop owners, as she imitated the way I spoke in front of them. I didn't have time to stop her because this is a disrespectful way to treat tourists and guests in general... Anyway, when I finally got to the bus stop, I found another queue, and we went to the bus, thank God... But the surprise was that there was another inspection before boarding the plane!!!! This caused the backlog and queues again!!!! One of the worst airport experiences in my life. Unprofessional and slow employees, poor airport management and organization. Finally, the plane didn't take off after this chaos until half an hour after the official takeoff time, and I was forced to stand during these three hours because of the boring and tiring queues. A bad experience by all standards.

TEXT: My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was shockingly poor and has completely soured my view of Malaysia. Arriving late at night, I was met with an appalling three-hour wait in the immigration queue. With only two counters open, the already tired and frustrated passengers were subjected to rude and unprofessional behavior from the immigration officers. One officer, who identified himself as Nizam, was particularly aggressive, yelling at passengers and making demeaning comments about their attempts to use the biometric scanners. His dismissive attitude and condescending tone were echoed by other staff members, creating a hostile and uncomfortable atmosphere for everyone, including families with young children. The situation worsened when, due to the extensive delay, our luggage was removed from the baggage carousel. This added further stress and inconvenience to an already exhausting experience. It felt as though the immigration staff treated their positions as some sort of celebrity status, rather than a service role. The impact of this disastrous airport experience rippled through my entire trip. I had to cancel some planned tourist attractions due to the excessive wait times I encountered elsewhere, including another two-hour queue. My children were exhausted, and our holiday was ultimately ruined. As if the airport ordeal wasn't enough, our tourist vehicle was later stopped by police for a seemingly pointless immigration check, resulting in another hour-long delay. This unnecessary display of authority felt like a final insult. It's ironic that Malaysia's economy relies heavily on tourism, yet visitors are treated with such disrespect. This entire experience was so negative that I will never visit Malaysia again. It's truly a shame, as I had hoped for a much more positive experience.

It 's ironic Malaysia 's economy rely heavily tourism , yet visitor treat disrespect . This entire experience negative I never visit Malaysia . It 's truly shame , I hop much positive experience .

TEXT: KLIA Terminal 1 is the worst airport in the world. I bought a drink at one of the shops inside the airport, but when I went through the gate security check, I was not allowed to bring my drink with me. Whats the point of the airport authorities allowing shops to sell items if those very products are considered a threat to aviation and are banned by airport security? As for the boarding process, it was very racist, as passengers with passports from certain countries were prioritized, while others from different countries were treated as second-class. Is this really worthy of being called an international airport when there is still discrimination in how passengers from different nationalities are treated? Perhaps I will never visit Malaysia again due to this terrible experience at KLIA Terminal 1

TEXT: Chaotic. We flew British Airways business class and it wasn't clear that we needed to go to gate G1, downstairs and take a bus to C gates, where Golden Lounge is. We walked around the main terminal being sent in random directions before being told the right information. At check in, we should have been told go to Gate G1 and take a bus. The Golden Lounge was very large. The bar is right near the entrance, so sit near there if you want to have a drink or two. Obviously the serving of alcohol is controlled here. I ordered two sparkling wines; one for my partner too but I was only served one. I had to ask for the second one and I felt judged for doing so. The glasses were small and the wine wasn't good. There was lots of hot food choices; far more than any other business lounge I have been too. Sandwiches, pasta and noodles made to order. Lots of other self-serve foods too. Don't try to take any drinks from the lounge, as you aren't allowed to take any onboard from this airport.

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers. These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member to go to C15 for a transfer to the arrival hall. Rather having a staff to shout ,wouldn't it be better to put up clear signage at both side of the walk way while we disembark? The signage for this bus transfer was unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus. Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldnt it be better to have basic international standard too? Situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall. The area was extremely crowded,people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration. Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic which leads to all these mess. After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for. The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when yiu have different groups of people surrounding the area....some was waiting for their friends while some was was looking for the right belt for their luggage. Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right. We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the Singapore Airlines logo on the floor. Quite a handful of luggage was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight were still stuck in immigration. Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt. Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage much of which was in Malay. This can be rather challenging, especially after a series of such "events" we went through. We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter, who knows we must go through the same things going back. On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.We have to endure our thirst till our flight take off. As a tourist, I dont enjoy it if I have to go through so much hassle. This was one of a kind of experience i wasn't expecting from KLIA... Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.
processed_text: I write provide feedback recent experience fly KLIA via Singapore Airlines . While I generally appreciate quality service Singapore Airlines flight , I disappoint experience KLIA , especially consider budget flight . Although large pack many shop eatery , area could improve facilitate smooth transit arrive passenger . These include clear directional signs/ large screen readily available information . Upon arrival , disembark plane , direct staff member go C15 transfer arrival hall . Rather staff shout , would n't good put clear signage side walk way disembark ? The signage bus transfer unclear , take u find area queue feeder bus . Would also suggest consider adjust volume announcement speaker loud clear information English , Chinese , Malay . Since name international , wouldnt good basic international standard ? Situation worsen upon arrival arrival hall . The area extremely crowd , people queue 2 -3 line row .... result queue hour clear immigration . Very disorganized messy , one direct human traffic lead mess . After clear immigration , locate correct baggage belt challenge . The area crowd , three four luggage belt need walk near belt check medium-sized monitor screen show flight belt mean . The screen flash fast many people try catch glimpse information , rather frustrating , especially yiu different group people surround area .... wait friend look right belt luggage . Literally , many passenger visibly struggle find luggage , move , leave right . We find luggage outside luggage belt area , sign Singapore Airlines logo floor . Quite handful luggage locate , obviously take flight still stick immigration . Imagine time take moment disembark plane get luggage leave outside belt . Navigating area find Grab also confuse due signage much Malay . This rather challenging , especially series `` event '' go . We think maybe common arrival passenger encounter , know must go thing go back . On return flight , require take short bus departure hall . TEXT: My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was unfortunately extremely disappointing. Firstly, the staff were generally unfriendly and appeared to have minimal understanding of English, which made basic communication difficult to impossible. More critically, there was a noticeable general incompetence across various functions. Staff seemed unable or unwilling to perform their duties, such as overseeing passengers and maintaining order in the queues. In this context, I repeatedly observed an absolute lack of professional supervision, where people were simply allowed to cut in line or where queues dissolved into chaos without any staff intervention. An additional major point of inefficiency was the self-service process: I was directed to the scanner by immigration staff, only for the scanner to then instruct me to return to the immigration counter, causing further unnecessary delays and frustration. Furthermore, the signage (wayfinding) was poor, often unclear, and lacked sufficient repetition throughout the terminal, making navigation difficult. To top it all off, there was also a lack of seating at the airport itself, and the seats that were available were often taken up by a single person lying down across three seats, leaving people who wanted to sit with nowhere to go. This combination of poor (and by times even disrespectful) customer service, language barriers, failure to enforce basic operational procedures and the lack of seating led to unnecessary stress and delays. It's clear that KLIA urgently needs to invest in significantly better training for its personnel, focusing on customer service, language proficiency, and core job efficiency. If I could give 0 stars, I would!

Staff seem unable unwilling perform duty , oversee passenger maintain order queue . In context , I repeatedly observe absolute lack professional supervision , people simply allow cut line queue dissolve chaos without staff intervention . An additional major point inefficiency self-service process : I direct scanner immigration staff , scanner instruct return immigration counter , cause unnecessary delay frustration . Furthermore , signage ( wayfinding ) poor , often unclear , lack sufficient repetition throughout terminal , make navigation difficult . To top , also lack seat , seat available often take single person lie across three seat , leave people want sit nowhere go . This combination poor ( time even disrespectful ) customer service , language barrier , failure enforce basic operational procedure lack seat lead unnecessary stress delay . It 's clear KLIA urgently need invest significantly good training personnel , focus customer service , language proficiency , core job efficiency . If I could give 0 star , I would !

TEXT: My second trip through Kuala Lumpur International Airport was unfortunately just as frustrating as the first. The customer service here is a huge problem. I asked multiple staff members for help with basic info, and every single one just shrugged, said "I don't know" and acted like it wasn't their job. There was zero effort to even try and find out. It's truly baffling. Then there's the internal airport bus with no proper monitoring. We had our 5-month-old with us and we literally had to stand for a 5-minute ride between gates. The bus wasn't even packed but everyone was too busy hogging their spot to offer one up to someone struggling with a baby. The fear of losing balance and dropping our infant was terrifying. People just sat there watching us, completely uncaring. To top it off, we saw a couple of electric buggies nearby, clearly for passenger assistance, but there was no one to drive them! We asked four different staff if they could help us get one, and each time, we got the same clueless "I don't know" response. For an international airport, the lack of basic help and common courtesy is really poor. Traveling with a baby is already tough enough, and KLIA just made it worse. I'll definitely be trying to avoid this airport next time.

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through a mall to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 PM, which was also the listed departure time, because it's too late now to buy tickets (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid over double the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia.

This logistical mess terrible first impression Malaysia .

TEXT: I visited Malaysia recently to attend a concert. I queued at immigration for almost two hours. When it was my turn, the officer did not smile or greet me back, despite my polite greeting. She only said Ticket? without explaining further. I showed my concert ticket, but she gave no response and told me to go back and queue again. I explained that I had already waited for over an hour, but she insisted without reason. Her tone and facial expressions were unfriendly, making my first impression of Malaysia very disappointing. Eventually, I showed all my documents and was allowed to pass. However, her attitude left a negative memory of the trip. I hope the management can provide proper training to ensure visitors are treated with courtesy.

I hope management provide proper training ensure visitor treat courtesy .

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always stood out for its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, is a beautiful highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of foreign and unique local offerings. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its due- the new bathrooms are a massive improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But I cant ignore the disappointing shift in retail and dining options. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. Also why is alcohol and tobacco taking up a large portion of the retail space every time? I was shocked to find only one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a foodie havenwhy isnt KLIA showcasing its rich culinary heritage and diversity? Gone are the great local options that once served authentic dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles and teh tarik. Instead, global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans dominate the F&B spaces. Surely, theres room for more homegrown eateries that represent Malaysias incredible food culture? To add to the frustration, the monorail is still not working, and travelers have to rely on shuttle buses- slow and less efficient. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phonecustomer service should be better than this. KLIA, we can do better! Support local businesses and bring back the true Malaysian experience.
processed_text: Ive travel KLIA countless time year , always stand cleanliness , smooth check-in process , efficient security check . The architecture , inspire Malaysian , Islamic , natural element , beautiful highlight . But truly make KLIA special balance foreign unique local offering . With recent KLIA1 renovation , I give credit due- new bathroom massive improvement ! Well-designed , clean , dry . But I cant ignore disappointing shift retail din option . Many local option disappear , replace foreign good . Also alcohol tobacco take large portion retail space every time ? I shock find one shelf Malaysian food product entire terminal 1 . Malaysia foodie havenwhy isnt KLIA showcasing rich culinary heritage diversity ? Gone great local option serve authentic dish like kaya toast , prawn noodle teh tarik . Instead , global chain like Starbucks Gloria Jeans dominate F & B space . Surely , there room homegrown eatery represent Malaysias incredible food culture ? To add frustration , monorail still work , traveler rely shuttle buses- slow less efficient . And I ask Ask Me For Help staff member food recommendation , barely look phonecustomer service good . KLIA , good ! Support local business bring back true Malaysian experience .

TEXT: It might be more appropriate to call it Kuala Lumpur Airport rather than 'International.' While the airport is generally clean and well-lit, the transit area is underwhelming. Wi-Fi connectivity is slow, and there are limited food and retail options. A significant upgrade or expansion is needed if the airport aims to keep up with other regional hubs. Additionally, the transport pick-up experience at Terminal 2 was a nightmare. The poorly designed two-lane pick-up area created severe congestion, and we ended up waiting over an hour just to be picked up. It's unclear who was responsible for this layout, but it clearly needs a serious rethink

TEXT: Ive traveled for over 10 years, and I have NEVER seen anything as poorly managed as Kuala Lumpur Airport. We were already waiting in line at the gate, yet we STILL almost missed our flight. How is that even possible?! Turns out, they check liquids right before the gateyes, AFTER security, after duty-free, after everything. This is the most illogical, frustrating, and time-wasting system I have ever experienced. People were rushing, confused, and stressed, while staff moved at a painfully slow pace. If you value your sanity, arrive ridiculously early or just avoid this airport altogether. Absolute chaos.

Turns , check liquid right gateyes , AFTER security , duty-free , everything . This illogical , frustrating , time-wasting system I ever experience . People rush , confuse , stress , staff move painfully slow pace . If value sanity , arrive ridiculously early avoid altogether . Absolute chaos .

TEXT: Highly Unprofessional Staff ( at least the one i dealt with ) waited almost 1.5 hours in the line there was my friend ahead of me and i was next. The lady officer she didnt asked him anything just held his passport and asked him to go to the immigration office ( He is a frequent traveller and has active visas for NZ and Uk ). I was next she saw me and told me to go too and doesnt even let me to go closer to the counter. We went to the immigration office and waited 6 hour for our number and when we were called the officer just asked me 2 questions literally 2 questions: 1 - How long you gonna stay. 2- Do you have a hotel booking. I was so heartbroken to hear these questions which the first officer could have asked me at the first place. I told the officer at the immigration about this whole scenario and she was shocked by herself and told me that she should not have sent me here and ask these questions by herself. Literally ruined my whole day almost 11 hours at the airport. Really disappointed because i was not expecting this kind of behaviour by a country which i was very excited to visit. If my review finds any person in charge please look into this matter. I know there are people who enters the country for illegal purposes like slipping or so but what about the legit tourists? There were hundreds of people dealing with the same thing. Its the job of officers to question and if they suspect something then send them for proper questioning. Dont judge by the ethnicity or nationality.

TEXT: (Emerites specifically from KL).. KL is a beautiful airport, super clean, very convenient with English signs everywhere- with many options for drink and food land side before security - coffee, mcdonalds, taco bell and high end malaysian restaurants. NOTE: the few Emirates flights that leave from here, despite what you may read, have NO bag drop, have no kiosks to print your bag tag or boarding pass, and if you are checking a bag you have to stand in the forever line with people going to Dubai with 5 giant suitcases. Not having an Emirates bag drop or kiosk is ridiculous. NOTE: Terminal C gates - the entire terminal stinks of cigarettes and the none care security has for looking at carry ons is terrifying. Many didnt even look at the screens, they were too busy dillydallying. Also note they dont use AC, at least in the C areas going international; its so hot people are passing out, fainting, getting sick from the heat and no air. Its stifling. There is no air circulating and its so bad, im even feeling nauseas.

TEXT: If you can avoid using this airport I would suggest in doing so. I have been in and out of KL a few times and each time has been a terrible experience. You will be charged fees you dont need to pay, wait in long queues and be sent to multiple stations around the airport. One particularly notable time recently was I waited so long to check in my baggage and we had told the staff our flight was soon. When I finally arrived at the counter the woman was fussing about. I asked her five times if there was an issue, and after ignoring me all those times she eventually told me my flight was boarding, so Id have to take the next flight. Once I asked her what the next time was she said 5pm, this meant I would have been stranded in Thailand with no accommodation as I needed to get a boat to where I was going. The last boat was at 6pm. After having multiple arguments with the staff a lovely man did escort us to our gate. There have honestly been multiple issues similarly at this airport, with unhelpful staff. This is coming from someone who is more than happy and patient to wait!

TEXT: The immigration staff at 2 a.m. this morning had a very bad attitude. The Malay woman had a brown body and was covered in thick powder. I was traveling from Bali to Kuala Lumpur for a three-day vacation when the staff suddenly started using rude and impolite language. I was just standing there with my Japanese husband. Because Indonesian and Japanese passports are handled differently, I couldn't see her face. Suddenly, she said, "You're rude! Why are you looking at me like that? You're rude." The female staff member with a Malay face said that. I said, "I've been quiet, not talking to you, and I haven't looked at you. Why are you coming to me? My face is like this. I've only been looking at my husband." When I get back from Malaysia, I'll take a picture of that immigration officer. He was on duty with a woman wearing a headscarf. It's really unethical to have Malay staff like that. Their attitude is very bad. Please, if you have problems at home, don't bring them to work. The female staff member with an Indian face is friendlier than the Malay one.

TEXT: For such a major international hub, the airport felt a little confusing and chaotic. We ran into the same issue two times - once on arrival (for transit) and once for departure. During arrival we wanted to switch from C Gates to A/B gates for domestic departure but it was confusing to find the directions. Exactly at the same location, during departure, we had to switch to C gates but got confused. We later realised that one of the sign boards is actually wrong. It points to an escalator upwards that goes into the shopping area. Whereas the C gates entry is exactly in the opposite direction of the sign. For an international airport this is not acceptable at all. I dont have photos, but getting confused at the same place two times is not right. We saw a few others get confused too. Apart from that there is no major security check and body scan before immigration. However this is done prior to boarding. This is not as per standard processes elsewhere wherein the detailed security check and body scan is done immediately at entry. Somehow disappointed with the airport.

During arrival want switch C Gates A/B gate domestic departure confuse find direction . Exactly location , departure , switch C gate get confuse . We later realise one sign board actually wrong . It point escalator upwards go shopping area . Whereas C gate entry exactly opposite direction sign . For international acceptable . I dont photo , get confuse place two time right . TEXT: KLIA is so huge, the potential clinical coldness of the facility is cleverly softened with what appears to be an atrium of greenery. The once state of the art facilities of this Airport is marred by the breakdown of the Aerotrain system that used to provide a world class service between the terminals. The Aerotrain gates have been hidden behind dark but colourful hoarding. Opposite the hoarding are lines of waiting passengers queuing to enter the various B gates, together with their various hand carry items. With poor lighting due to the height of the dark colourd hoarding, this creates a somewhat long dark narrow somber passage that arriving visitors to Malaysia must navigate to reach the escalators to the ground level and transfer bus terminal. Any negative impressions arising from negotiating past the queuing passengers with unsettled infants and the ocassional unrestrained child darting into the crowd flow is further accentuated as one reaches the ground level and confronted by the multinational crowd chaos at the Satellite Terminal bus transfer gate. The airport employees manning the area do a great job in moving the crowd in arbitrary groups onto the waiting buses. Despite the apparent crowd chaos, these Malaysian employees at various informal "gates" manage to prevent a crowd surge and create controlled access on to the buses. These lowly front line employees are the true heroes in this situation and are living examples of the "Malaysia Boleh" can-do attitude. It's such a pity senior Airport management doesn't display a similar level of commitment in getting the Aerotrain system fixed and creating a positive first impression for international arrivals to Malaysia.

The state art facility Airport mar breakdown Aerotrain system use provide world class service terminal . The Aerotrain gate hide behind dark colourful hoarding . Opposite hoarding line wait passenger queue enter various B gate , together various hand carry item . With poor light due height dark colourd hoarding , create somewhat long dark narrow somber passage arrive visitor Malaysia must navigate reach escalator ground level transfer bus terminal . The employee man area great job move crowd arbitrary group onto wait bus . These lowly front line employee true hero situation live example `` Malaysia Boleh '' can-do attitude . It 's pity senior Airport management n't display similar level commitment get Aerotrain system fix create positive first impression international arrival Malaysia .

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member, who was shouting, to proceed to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall by bus. Was thinking that perhaps our flight was scheduled to park in a further lot due to multiple flights arriving around the same time,which requires us to do a short transit. Personally, I wasnt expecting to go through the hassle of having to transit from the plane to the arrival hall, taking into consideration that this was a direct flight. Anyway, still went with the flow and follow those in front since we are told to.... This information could easily be missed if people are talking or focused on finding the nearest toilet. Although the airport was large and packed with lots of shops and eateries, there are areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving/departure passengers. Would suggest the following improvements: * Rather than having a staff member shouting/giving instructions, can consider placing clear, large signage on both sides of the walkway as passengers disembark. * Provide more readily available information upon flight arrival / departure. * Consider adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Clear directional signs and information would make a big difference for first-time visitors like myself and would save a lot of time especially when there are so many incoming/outgoing flights day to day..... The signage for the bus transfer was unclear, and it took approximately 4-5 minutes to find the waiting point to queue for the feeder bus to the arrival hall. Upon arriving at the arrival hall, it was another 2-minute walk to reach immigration. The area was extremely crowded, with queues of 2-3 lines in a row, resulting in an hour-long wait to clear immigration. The process was very disorganized and messy, with no one managing the human traffic, possibly due to a shortage of manpower. Although the officers were friendly and efficient in clearing the queue, it would be beneficial to have crowd control/security to guide and manage the flow of passengers. Locating the correct baggage belt after clearing immigration was another challenge. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts, requiring passengers to walk near the belt to check the monitor screen. This was frustrating, especially with different groups of people surrounding the area, some looking for directions, some waiting for friends, and others searching for the right belt. We eventually found our luggage placed not far away from the luggage belt area near the exit, with a sign displaying the SQ Airlines logo on the floor. Many unclaimed bags from our flight were present, as most passengers were still stuck in immigration. The entire process, from disembarking the plane to retrieving our luggage outside the baggage claim area, was challenging. I thought we were only required to transit to the arrival hall as a one-time occurrence. However, on our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient. As a tourist, the airport gives the first impression for passengers, and its organization is crucial. I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements

TEXT: I had a deeply frustrating and disappointing experience at Kuala Lumpur Airport due to the unprofessionalism and rudeness of the staff. Upon arrival, I realized I had accidentally left my luggage in the restroom near the baggage claim. When I approached the information desk to ask for help, I received conflicting and unhelpful instructions. Some staff told me to go to the second floor, while others asked me to use an invalid boarding pass to re-enter security (which was impossible since my ticket was for a domestic flight from Kota Kinabalu). I ended up running back and forth between the second and third floors more than ten times, but no one took responsibility or provided any real assistance. Desperate, I approached a female staff member at the exit to request her help in checking the restroom for my luggage. Not only was she extremely reluctant, but she also glared at me in a hostile manner. After being persuaded by her colleague, she finally went to check the restroom. Within less than a minute, she came back and coldly told me my luggage wasnt there, claiming to have confirmed with the cleaning staff. However, this was simply not possible. Two hours later, left with no other options, I asked a passenger who hadnt exited yet to help me check the restroom. In just three minutes, they returned with my luggage. This experience was utterly unacceptable. The staffs lack of professionalism, unwillingness to help, and outright rudeness made an already stressful situation even worse. An airport should prioritize assisting passengers, not adding to their frustration. I hope the management will take serious steps to train their staff to ensure such incidents dont happen again.

Upon arrival , I realize I accidentally leave luggage restroom near baggage claim . When I approach information desk ask help , I receive conflict unhelpful instruction . I end run back forth second third floor ten time , one take responsibility provide real assistance . Desperate , I approach female staff member exit request help check restroom luggage . Not extremely reluctant , also glare hostile manner . After persuade colleague , finally go check restroom . Within less minute , come back coldly tell luggage wasnt , claim confirm cleaning staff . The staffs lack professionalism , unwillingness help , outright rudeness make already stressful situation even bad . An prioritize assist passenger , add frustration . I hope management take serious step train staff ensure incident dont happen .

TEXT: Unfortunately, my experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was disappointing. Here are a few points that struck me negatively: 1. Strict baggage control, but not consistent: My hand luggage was accurately weighed, and even though it was only slightly over 7kg, I was told to pay extra. At the same time, the Malaysian woman in front of me, weighing almost 8 kg, was allowed to walk away - that felt unfair. 2. Poor Signage: Some gates had no numbers, which was extremely confusing. It was difficult to find the right path. 3. Lack of seating: There were no seats at the gate, which made the wait unnecessarily tiring. 4. Inadequate Toilets: The women's restrooms were a mess - I waited in line for over 30 minutes and when it was finally my turn, they were dirty. The men apparently had enough toilets as there were no queues. Last but not least, our flight was delayed. Unfortunately, the airport was the worst I've ever been to.

At time , Malaysian woman front , weigh almost 8 kg , allow walk away - felt unfair . 2 . Poor Signage : Some gate number , extremely confuse . It difficult find right path . 3 . Lack seating : There seat gate , make wait unnecessarily tire . 4 . Inadequate Toilets : The woman 's restroom mess - I wait line 30 minute finally turn , dirty . The men apparently enough toilet queue . Last least , flight delay . Unfortunately , bad I 've ever .

TEXT: The airport is a bit of a misunderstanding. Upon arrival, you find yourself in a common corridor with departure gates. There are no signs indicating where to go. There's a security check. But! The Wi-Fi works well. There's duty-free shopping upon arrival. They say you can only pay with local currency, but I haven't personally verified this information. Safe flights, everyone!

TEXT: Edit:DO NOT USE GRAB ehailing, especially advance booking. Use BOLT. Your welcome for cheaper ride. bypass airport expensive surcharge by using trains. Use the ERL and drop off at Salak Tinggi. And you can get cheaper ehailing ride. Dear traveler, do NOT use "taxi" that waiting at the airport. They "offer" you a ride for rm300-400. You should only get a ride via ehailing service, I recommended BOLT. A ride from airport to Kuala Lumpur should not exceed RM80, MAX. If a 4 seats it RM50 MAX. If you book an ehailing, driver can't ask more money from you. Pay what in the app. If driver ask for more money, record them & car number plate, and go to police station to submit a report. Those driver who doesn't use the app / ask for more money is the betrayal to Malaysia.

TEXT: One of the worst airport experiences Ive ever had. Immigration alone took more than 2 hours, followed by 45 minutes at customs. The officers were consistently rude, arrogant, and completely unprofessional no courtesy, no efficiency, just laziness on full display. To make things worse, the airport itself is extremely poorly managed. Signs are unclear and confusing, and there are no staff around to guide or assist passengers. Youre left standing in endless queues without any explanation, while officers act like theyre doing you a favor by simply being there. For an international gateway, KLIA fails miserably. Instead of welcoming travelers, it creates frustration and leaves a terrible first impression of Malaysia: slow, lazy, and rude.

TEXT: The experience at this airport is nothing short of disgraceful. Staff are unprofessional, careless, and shockingly rude. Instead of guiding passengers, they raise their voices and shout in peoples faces, turning simple situations into unnecessary stress. The process is chaotic: passengers are forced through security three times, and reaching the gate feels like an exhausting obstacle course. There is no friendliness, no respect, and certainly no sense of hospitality. On top of that, if you bring dutyfree cigarettes purchased from another airport, they will either confiscate them or force you to pay tax more than their actual value. It feels less like an international airport and more like a place designed to exploit travelers.

TEXT: This was by far the worst and most unacceptable experience Ive ever had with any airline. At the Batik Air baggage counter in Kuala Lumpur before flight OD171 to Denpasar, I was shouted at, threatened, and pressured into paying a baggage fee of 650 MYR, with the amount changing several times without explanation. First it was more, then less, then suddenly 650 it was chaotic and clearly unprofessional. The staff member at the baggage scale used aggressive language, raised their voice, and intimidated me in front of other passengers. I felt unsafe and coerced. This was not a normal excess baggage fee it felt like extortion. I complied because I felt I had no choice. This is absolutely not the standard I expect from any airline, especially not from Batik Air, which previously had my trust. I have filed a formal complaint with the airline and am awaiting a refund and investigation. I strongly warn other travelers: If youre flying from Kuala Lumpur with Batik Air, be cautious at the baggage counter. Keep records, film interactions, and dont let yourself be bullied.

This normal excess baggage fee felt like extortion . I comply I felt I choice . This absolutely standard I expect airline , especially Batik Air , previously trust . TEXT: KLIA1 has undergone a number of upgrades in the past couple of years, particularly in terms of dining options on Level 5's Departure Hall (before security/immigration control) and duty-free shopping (after security/immigration control) in the main terminal. Work is still ongoing and hopefully we'll continue to see improvements in the months to come. My main problem with KLIA1 is the absence of any water refill stations at the passenger waiting area (boarding gates) after security clearance. Being a frequent flyer who's flown in and out of so many airports around the world, KLIA1 remains the only big airport that doesn't have this facility made available to passengers. I don't understand why the airport just doesn't address this issue as it's causing passengers (e.g., parents, senior travellers, etc.) so much inconvenience. Once passengers clears security, they won't access to any drinking water until they board their flight. Surely this is a shortcoming that can be easily fixed by the airport administrator...yet it remains the same month after month after month. @KLA1 - If you see this review, please provide some water refill stations for the convenience and comfort of your passengers. That's be much appreciated!

TEXT: Worst immigration experience in international airports compared to other major transit airports in Asia i.e Dubai, Doha, Istanbul and Bangkok airports. Immigration in the country took more than 1.5 hours and system was down so they had to do manual entries. On the way back. It took more than 2 hours. I had to request few people to let go of their turn so that I don't miss my flight. Only one counter for a queue of about 50 people. There was this lady at the counter. She took more than 30 mins on one couple! FGS either accept or reject. Very un progressional behavior by the immigration staff. This long wait made me miss my visit to chocolate shops as only 20 mins were left after the immigration clears. Moreover, for international departures you have to take a bus to another lounge. Which is weird for such a developed country. The shops inside are nice and many food options are available. Mosque is available on 3rd level. Have to search for it or ask for directions from the staff. If some one wishes to connect a domestic flight directly with the international keep at least 3 hours buffer. Always book within the same literary. Keep at least 2 hours for the immigration clearance. Such a pathetic and slow service. Even countries such as Pakistan and KSA have better immigration services.

TEXT: I had two layovers at KLIA. The first time, everything went well: the airport was clean, well-organized, and especially a well-appointed prayer room, which is really appreciated by Muslim travelers. However, the second time was a completely different story, as if it weren't even the same place. As soon as you get off the plane, nothing is clear: there's almost no signage for baggage claim. It's easy to get lost, you don't know where to go. And then, surprise: you have to go through security and immigration before claiming your baggage. Completely illogical. At least let me collect my bag peacefully first! Once you're through immigration, you arrive in a huge crowd, with no smooth flow of traffic. Then you have to go through security again to get out. You board, you get off, you take a bus, you change buildings... frankly, a real hassle. Another point: the baggage counter agents are extremely strict, sometimes even abusive. If you weigh 5 kg more than you need, you pay, period, no flexibility. The prayer rooms? They used to be clean, now they're dilapidated, not maintained. Really a shame. Finally, I had a three-hour layover, I barely had time to navigate the obstacle course to get to my gate. And guess what? 40 minutes into the flight, our gate was changed from 35 to 4. Great. And then, as a Muslim, I felt uneasy. For a country I considered a brother, I had never felt so foreign. Clearly, Asian passengers are given priority. Sad to say, but I felt a real form of nationalism. In short, very disappointed. I didn't find the welcome I was hoping for in a country like Malaysia.

However , second time completely different story , n't even place . As soon get plane , nothing clear : 's almost signage baggage claim . It 's easy get lose , n't know go . And , surprise : go security immigration claim baggage . Completely illogical . At least let collect bag peacefully first ! Once 're immigration , arrive huge crowd , smooth flow traffic . Then go security get . You board , get , take bus , change building ... frankly , real hassle . Another point : baggage counter agent extremely strict , sometimes even abusive . If weigh 5 kg need , pay , period , flexibility . The prayer room ? They use clean , 're dilapidate , maintain . Really shame . Finally , I three-hour layover , I barely time navigate obstacle course get gate . And guess ? 40 minute flight , gate change 35 4 . Great . And , Muslim , I felt uneasy . For country I consider brother , I never felt foreign . Clearly , Asian passenger give priority . Sad say , I felt real form nationalism . In short , disappointed . I n't find welcome I hop country like Malaysia .

TEXT: Travel Tips for Kuala Lumpur: Save Money on Airport Transfers Avoid Grab e-Hailing, Especially Advance Bookings Grab drivers, particularly for advance bookings, may overcharge or provide subpar service. Instead, use Bolt for a more affordable and reliable ride. Bypass Airport Surcharges with Trains To avoid high airport ride-hailing fees, take the Express Rail Link (ERL) to Salak Tinggi station. From there, book a ride via Bolt for a significantly cheaper fare. Steer Clear of Airport Taxis Avoid taxis waiting at the airport, as they often charge exorbitant rates (RM300400). Opt for e-hailing services like Bolt, where fares to Kuala Lumpur should not exceed RM80 for a standard car or RM50 for a 4-seater. Know Your Rights with E-Hailing With e-hailing apps, pay only the fare shown in the app. If a driver demands extra payment, record their details (name, car plate number, and interaction) and report it to the nearest police station. Such behavior violates fair practices and harms Malaysias reputation. Pro Tip: Always book rides through trusted apps like Bolt for transparency and savings. Safe travels!

TEXT: I'm a Japanese tourist. I came on AirAsia via HIS. When I returned to Japan, I was constantly told to check in at the machine, and even when I went to the machine, I was asked for my reservation number. However, the document from HIS does not have a reservation number written on it. Therefore, even if you go to the counter again and say, "You can't check in using the machine!", they just insist that you "check in using the machine." So when I looked back at my HIS documents, I found a form that was difficult to understand and required me to show the staff in English that I couldn't check in using the machine. However, even if I showed them my English, the staff was insistent that I check in using the machine. After that, I managed to check in, but... Please be careful if you are going to Kuala Lumpur on HIS AirAsia. Mr. HIS, is this okay? I feel sorry for the Japanese people who will be traveling in the future.

TEXT: KLIA is an international airport that always feels like a poor budget airport that is falling apart. Ironically, it is overstaffed by an army of smiling greeters. On Sunday, 22 June 2025, we saw water dispenser stations broken and unrepaired. "Free drinks" stations abandoned, unmanned. The only smoking room in the airport is a filthy room covered in black soot: incredibly smelly, no ventilation systems, piles of ash, trash, and butts all over. Warning: Enter at your own risk. The aerotrain was being repaired, and although bus services were provided, no signs were available to passengers on where it is. Bus services from the sub terminal to the main terminal were not easy to find. Tragically, the contrast between KLIA and KLIA2 (the latter an actual budget terminal that's well designed, modern, clean, and efficient) has never been clearer. TEXT: Extremely Disappointed Misleading Prices and Poor Service I had a very disappointing experience at this caf in the Malaysian International Airport. The prices displayed on the product tags were already quite high, but when I went to pay, I was suddenly asked to pay more due to additional taxes that were not shown upfront. This kind of pricing is misleading and unfair, especially in an international airport where transparency should be standard. To make matters worse, when I questioned the price difference, the staff refused to give me what I had selected unless I paid the extra hidden charges. I ended up leaving without my purchase. Travelers deserve honesty, clear pricing, and respectnot surprises at the counter. I hope airport management takes this seriously and enforces proper pricing standards. I would not recommend this caf to anyone.

TEXT: KLIA is so huge, the potential clinical coldness of the facility is cleverly softened with what appears to be an atrium of greenery. The once state of the art facilities of this Airport is marred by the breakdown of the Aerotrain system that used to provide a world class service between the terminals. The Aerotrain gates have been hidden behind dark but colourful hoarding. Opposite the hoarding are lines of waiting passengers queuing to enter the various B gates, together with their various hand carry items. With poor lighting due to the height of the dark colourd hoarding, this creates a somewhat long dark narrow somber passage that arriving visitors to Malaysia must navigate to reach the escalators to the ground level and transfer bus terminal. Any negative impressions arising from negotiating past the queuing passengers with unsettled infants and the ocassional unrestrained child darting into the crowd flow is further accentuated as one reaches the ground level and confronted by the multinational crowd chaos at the Satellite Terminal bus transfer gate. The airport employees manning the area do a great job in moving the crowd in arbitrary groups onto the waiting buses. Despite the apparent crowd chaos, these Malaysian employees at various informal "gates" manage to prevent a crowd surge and create controlled access on to the buses. These lowly front line employees are the true heroes in this situation and are living examples of the "Malaysia Boleh" can-do attitude. It's such a pity senior Airport management doesn't display a similar level of commitment in getting the Aerotrain system fixed and creating a positive first impression for international arrivals to Malaysia.

The state art facility Airport mar breakdown Aerotrain system use provide world class service terminal . The Aerotrain gate hide behind dark colourful hoarding . With poor light due height dark colourd hoarding , create somewhat long dark narrow somber passage arrive visitor Malaysia must navigate reach escalator ground level transfer bus terminal . Any negative impression arise negotiate past queue passenger unsettled infant ocassional unrestrained child dart crowd flow accentuate one reach ground level confront multinational crowd chaos Satellite Terminal bus transfer gate . The employee man area great job move crowd arbitrary group onto wait bus .
