These lowly front line employee true hero situation live example `` Malaysia Boleh '' can-do attitude . It 's pity senior Airport management n't display similar level commitment get Aerotrain system fix create positive first impression international arrival Malaysia .

TEXT: Hands down the most inefficient airport Ive had the displeasure of travelling to 1. Pointless arriving early because your gate isnt available and you end up waiting on the tarmac without air conditioning. Not enough leeway between departing / arriving flights and no backup plan 2. You often arrive at the departures gate rather than arrivals and need to take a bus to arrivals / passport control, which is a waste of time. The new aerotrain has been out of action for over 2yrs with completion dates, unsurprisingly, being delayed several times. 3. If you havent already been severely frustrated by the first 2 points, wait till you arrive at passport control. Only 2 (max 3) of the booths are open and staff are slow, disinterested and have no desire to speed up the process, as though they revel in seeing their visitors suffer. This has been an issue for years with numerous local articles about it but efficiency and an improvement mindset simply does not exist in certain parts of the world.

TEXT: I was assaulted by a female airport passenger experience officer who attempted to physically restrain me without justification. When I demanded to file a police report, I was told I would have to go to Terminal 2something my Australian emergency passport did not permit. Despite my repeated requests, the airport police refused to take my report and instead escorted me to the immigration department. There, I was met by an aggressive and unprofessional immigration officer named Kamarudin. When I asked for his full name in writing, he refused and rudely pointed to his name badge, telling me to take a photo with my phone. The moment I did, he became enraged and began intimidating meeven going so far as to take photos of me and my passport on his personal phone. This was a blatant violation of privacy and professional conduct. **Malaysias airport authorities and immigration officers behaved in a disgusting, abusive, and unaccountable manner. Travelers beware: AVOID MALAYSIA at all costs!** **Legal Analysis** This conduct raises multiple violations under Malaysian law: 1. **Assault and Criminal Force (Penal Code Sections 350-352)** The staff member's actions in grabbing my arms and physically restraining me without consent constitutes criminal force under Section 350. Case precedent (PP v. Mohd Anuar bin Abdullah [1994] 2 MLJ 261) confirms that any intentional use of force without lawful justification meets this threshold. 2. **Wrongful Confinement (Penal Code Section 340)** The unlawful restriction of my movement within the clinic treatment room amounts to wrongful confinement. Malaysian jurisprudence establishes that detention without legal authority is punishable, particularly where no legitimate lien exists over the person. 3. **Official Misconduct** The behavior of Immigration Officer Kamarudin in: - Failing to properly address a criminal complaint - Intimidating a complainant - Improper use of personal devices to photograph sensitive documents May constitute offenses under Malaysia's official misconduct provisions. UPDATE: Malaysian Airport Management have promised a full investigation of this matter however no official response as of yet.

When I demand file police report , I tell I would go Terminal 2something Australian emergency passport permit . Despite repeated request , police refuse take report instead escort immigration department . There , I meet aggressive unprofessional immigration officer name Kamarudin . When I ask full name writing , refuse rudely point name badge , tell take photo phone . The moment I , become enraged begin intimidate meeven go far take photo passport personal phone . This blatant violation privacy professional conduct . * * Malaysias authority immigration officer behave disgusting , abusive , unaccountable manner . Travelers beware : AVOID MALAYSIA cost ! * * * * Legal Analysis * * This conduct raise multiple violation Malaysian law : 1 . * * Assault Criminal Force ( Penal Code Sections 350-352 ) * * The staff member 's action grab arm physically restrain without consent constitutes criminal force Section 350 . Case precedent ( PP v. Mohd Anuar bin Abdullah [ 1994 ] 2 MLJ 261 ) confirms intentional use force without lawful justification meet threshold . 2 . * * Wrongful Confinement ( Penal Code Section 340 ) * * The unlawful restriction movement within clinic treatment room amount wrongful confinement . Malaysian jurisprudence establishes detention without legal authority punishable , particularly legitimate lien exist person . 3 . * * Official Misconduct * * The behavior Immigration Officer Kamarudin : - Failing properly address criminal complaint - Intimidating complainant - Improper use personal device photograph sensitive document May constitute offense Malaysia 's official misconduct provision . UPDATE : Malaysian Airport Management promise full investigation matter however official response yet .

TEXT: Worst airport I've ever been to!!! Check-in/baggage drop took forever (despite online check-in) and there were also very long queues at the passport controls. So definitely plan plenty of time. We were there over 3 hours earlier, but in the end it was very close. There are few signs and information boards in the airport. DANGER!!! The absolute shame is the controls in front of the individual gates (no information about them beforehand). AFTER going through the duty free shop area, you will have to go through security checkpoints again and drink/throw away all of the liquids you purchased there. You even have to destroy the water you bought for the flight. In the area between security check and the plane there is no longer any possibility to buy drinks/food (nor any possibility to refill your empty bottle with water) or to go to the toilet. When I asked where I could get something to drink, all I got was an annoyed Buy in Plane. For a city like Kuala Lumpur, this airport is an absolute disgrace.

TEXT: The airport looks very fancy and all - at least Terminal 1. It is very unorganized though. We arrived extremely late from our first flight (thank you batik air) and only had 15-20min to get our connecting flight. Normally airports would provide a shuttle services, picking you from a gate to bring you to your connecting flight in time. This was not the case here, we were only told the gate number of our connecting flight, which after running to for 10min, turned out to be the wrong gate. So instead we had to take the bus to another terminal, which obviously did not give us enough time to catch our flight, so we were stuck in KL for 1 night. Additionally it is ridiculous, that there is no smoking area in the entirety of terminal 1. So if you are stuck here for a while you have to go all the way to terminal 2, into one of the most disgusting smoking rooms Ive witnessed in my life (no ventilation at all, might as well just walk in and breath twice and youve already passively smoked a carton of cigarettes). Really disappointing for such a modern (only t1) and large airport.

TEXT: Worst transit experience ever. The lounge and gate areas are chilled to fridge temperature You cant even go to the bathroom, because they are either closed for cleaning (but no one is cleaning) or they are open, but guarded by a cleaner who will follow you to the toilet and will wait outside the door to clean up right after. I dont know about others but to me this feels extremely uncomfortable. Very few public seating areas (only near the center) and they are not lit and very dark. Air has a strong kerosine smell to it. Has security checks directly at the gate (at least for our flight). The quests there are looooooooong and they use older scanners (electronics need to be taken out, watches and belts need to be taken off, ), which makes everyone take an incredibly long time to go through the screening. Only good point we had was the piano they had set up, that anyone can play on.

TEXT: It will be the last airport on Earth youd ever want to fly to or from. The gate numbers change constantly, often right before the designated boarding time. Before you board, youre forced to toss your water with no option to refill, leaving you reliant on the airplane for hydration. The train link between the main terminal and the satellite has been out of service for years. The security line before the gate is a complete joke and a massive waste of time. Its truly the most dreadful airport on Earth, and it pales in comparison to world-class airports like Changi or even Suvarnabhumi.

TEXT: A terrible place. We flew here at night for the first time. Filling out the online formwe didn't like either the number or the email addresstook half an hour. Even in the relatively empty airport, we had problems. The electronic barrier wouldn't let Russian passports through, for some unknown reason, so much so that even the staff didn't know how to help. We ended up staying at a regular hotel where the staff were sleeping. Then we searched for a hotel right next to the airport. We ended up sleeping there for five hours out of the planned eight because checkout was at 10:00 AM. We arrived back during the day. The staff offered to complete the electronic history check, but the check-in line was insane, an hour and a half long, and very few windows for migrants were open.

TEXT: Worst immigration experience in international airports compared to other major transit airports in Asia i.e Dubai, Doha, Istanbul and Bangkok airports. Immigration in the country took more than 1.5 hours and system was down so they had to do manual entries. On the way back. Immigration took more than 2 hours. I had to request few people to let go of their turn so that I don't miss my flight. Only one counter for a queue of about 50 people(Normally takes 30 mins at other airports, however, the Malaysia made sure 50 people took 2 hours). There was this lady at the counter. She took more than 30 mins on one couple! FGS either accept or reject. Very un progressional behavior by the immigration staff. This long wait made me miss my visit to chocolate shops as only 20 mins were left after the immigration clears. Moreover, for international departures you have to take a bus to another lounge. Which is weird for such a developed country. The shops inside are nice and many food options are available. Mosque is available on 3rd level. Have to search for it or ask for directions from the staff. If some one wishes to connect a domestic flight directly with the international keep at least 3 hours buffer. Always book within the same literary. Keep at least 2 hours for the immigration clearance. Such a pathetic and slow service. Even countries such as Pakistan and KSA have better immigration services. The flight was ready to depart after boarding and other checks have been completed. However, it took more than 10 minutes for our plane to get permission to get on the runway. Malaysia wants to attract tourists ? Please invest in your airport and immigration services. Thank you

TEXT: KLIA is an international airport that always feels like a poor budget airport that is falling apart. Ironically, it is overstaffed by an army of smiling greeters. On Sunday, 22 June 2025, we saw water dispenser stations broken and unrepaired. "Free drinks" stations abandoned, unmanned. The only smoking room in the airport is a filthy room covered in black soot: incredibly smelly, no ventilation systems, piles of ash, trash, and butts all over. Warning: Enter at your own risk. The aerotrain was being repaired, and although bus services were provided, no signs were available to passengers on where it is. Bus services from the sub terminal to the main terminal were not easy to find. Tragically, the contrast between KLIA and KLIA2 (the latter an actual budget terminal that's well designed, modern, clean, and efficient) has never been clearer. If KLIA2 is a Budget airport, then KLIA should be called a "No Budget" Airport.
processed_text: KLIA international always feel like poor budget fall apart . Ironically , overstaffed army smile greeter . On Sunday , 22 June 2025 , saw water dispenser station break unrepaired . `` Free drink '' station abandon , unmanned . The smoking room filthy room cover black soot : incredibly smelly , ventilation system , pile ash , trash , butt . Warning : Enter risk . The aerotrain repair , although bus service provide , sign available passenger . Bus service sub terminal main terminal easy find . Tragically , contrast KLIA KLIA2 ( latter actual budget terminal 's well design , modern , clean , efficient ) never clear . If KLIA2 Budget , KLIA call `` No Budget '' Airport .

TEXT: Flight at 705am, we were ask to cross the checkpoint into immigration by 605am. We were 5 mins late, denied enterence, got ping pong around different department for 30mins. Ultimately it was the information counter that seems to know what to do, got into contact with the airline, but it was too late because of the time wasted by the ground crew that doesn't seems to know where to direct us. Airline ground crew are locals, seemed oblivious and gave us the not my problem attitude. Later we went to the airline office to check on how to retrieve our baggage, the staff's attitude was so poor with all the lecturing when we had been running around for 45mins and are in distress. Yes it was our fault for being 5mins late, she could had shown some empathy in her choice if words even though there's nothing she could had done. That's the reality of Malaysian hospitality. 1st class on the surface, 3rd world attitude and mentality. I've seem way more polite and helpful staff in China and Singapore.

TEXT: Compared to this airport, Incheon Airport is heaven. Kuala Lumpur Airport is a real pain in the ass for both departure and arrival. TEXT: It's the capital airport of a big country It's hot because they turned on the air conditioner. And there's a lot of shopping. Malaysia is a beggar who's become rich~ Of course, the price is expensive, and even that's almost nonexistent after security. Smokers, you must stop by the smoking room before security. If you go all the way to the corner before the P and Q gates, you'll find the smoking room. After security, it's crowded with people waiting~ It's hard to find a chair~ The structure and area are very stuffy, and it's hard to find any amenities. This is the worst experience. It's not even worth one star!

One pointing left and the other sign pointed right. I saw few customers including aircrew staff were confused and didn't know which way to go. Further, the staff was staring at me while was brusing teeth at the washroom at 6am. I realised she's waiting to clean my spot after I finished brushing. She either come back rather than just staring at me. I felt so unconfmy and I was the only passenger there. I went other less modern airport like ho chi Ming city or in Istanbul. Where still have better experience than in Malaysia

TEXT: Drinking water is a major issue at the airport and there are several reviews mentioning this but nothing has changed. You are not allowed to take your water beyond security which is understandable but how can you not have water filling stations or even bottled water for people waiting to board? It's quite disappointing and shocking, and can be a big issue especially for elderly passengers and those with health issues. In a hot and humid climate, access to drinking water is essential. Unfortunately, there are no water refill stations or bottled water available after security. If there is a flight delay, passengers are left waiting for hours without water. I've been to several airports and never had this issue, just look at Singapore airport where there are water refill facilities everywhere. I strongly urge the airport authorities to look into this and provide better facilities for water access after security. The current conditions are simply unacceptable especially for the elderly and those with health issues.

TEXT: I had one of the worst airport experiences at Kuala Lumpur International Airport, Terminal 2. Upon arrival, we were met with confusing procedures and zero proper guidance on how to complete the entry process. The Arrive app they require is completely unnecessary, buggy, and slows everything down. There was no one clearly assigned to assist passengers, and the process made no sense. To make matters worse, we approached a uniformed police officer for help, who rudely dismissed us and refused to offer any kind of support. His tone was aggressive, unprofessional, and completely inappropriate for someone representing airport security. Instead of helping travelersmany of whom were clearly confused and exhaustedhe seemed more interested in scolding people. The lack of signage, the useless app, and untrained or unwilling staff made the whole arrival process feel hostile and disorganized. For a country that depends on tourism, this kind of treatment is unacceptable. I wont be flying into KLIA Terminal 2 again anytime soon.

For country depend tourism , kind treatment unacceptable . I wont fly KLIA Terminal 2 anytime soon .

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, because it's too late now to buy tickets (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid over double the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. Oh and did I mention that the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration? I had such a hard time to book the Grab and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, because there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!! This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

Yes , literal mall every world 'd check transportation finally leave . After long flight , last thing anyone want drag maze store leave . It felt like cash grab , travel hub . We finally make relieve see Grab available ( use Thailand ) . But book ride , wait time 35 minute ! There huge , overcrowd Grab wait area screen show incoming car plate , clearly , demand way beyond could handle . Tired frustrate , give Grab , hop catch bus instead . But werent allow buy ticket exactly 12 AM , also list departure time bus , 's late buy ticket ( 15 minute ahead ) . We tell bus would leave even 12 . The whole thing felt disorganized unclear wait time seem Grab destination station even close hotel . In end , pay double Grab fare take regular taxi , get hell . Oh I mention wifi available finish immigration ? I hard time book Grab check information chat airbnb host wifi immigration , 's freakin ' mall exit ! ! ! This logistical mess terrible first impression Malaysia . I 've never think would affect visit country .

TEXT: Dear traveler, do NOT use "taxi" that waiting at the airport. They "offer" you a ride for rm300-400. You should only get a ride via ehailing service, I recommended BOLT. Pay what in the app. If driver ask for more money, record them & car number plate, and go to police station to submit a report. Those driver who doesn't use the app / ask for more money is the betrayal to Malaysia.

TEXT: Arriving: Immigration for arrivals took too long! The officers works so slowly and the poor internet connection in this area is not helping either. It took us long enough to complete immigration to the point that our bags were no longer in the conveyor belt/shown on screen. Pick up location of ride hailing (Grab) was easy at Level 1. Departure: Check in counters are spread out making it not too crowded/congested. Immigration for departure is quicker and easier. However, there's a security screening for customs departure that was separated with at-gate security check. I would say this is very inefficient as you need to check your bags twice and once you have cleared security you practically cannot go out to the retail area. This also lead to congestion during Gate Open as people would avoid coming to it and come as late as possible. Security at the gate is so slow. In addition, the post-security gate is a nightmare with neither water stations nor proper toilet! There seems to be no signs of priority boarding based on group but rather by seats (not sure if this is an MH or KLIA problem). Retail space is decent with great tax-free goods options and decent restaurant selections. One thing to appreciate: the toilets (in retail & public) areas are clean and equipped with jet showers.

Immigration departure quick easy . However , 's security screening custom departure separate at-gate security check . I would say inefficient need check bag twice clear security practically go retail area . This also lead congestion Gate Open people would avoid come come late possible . Security gate slow . In addition , post-security gate nightmare neither water station proper toilet ! There seem sign priority board base group rather seat ( sure MH KLIA problem ) . Retail space decent great tax-free good option decent restaurant selection . One thing appreciate : toilet ( retail & public ) area clean equip jet shower .

TEXT: I had an extremely frustrating experience with the immigration process at this airport. The service was painfully slow, with long queues that seemed to move at a snails pace despite there being multiple counters. It felt disorganized and inefficient from the moment I arrived. What made it worse was the attitude of some of the immigration officers. Several of them appeared moody and unapproachable, offering no guidance or courtesy. Instead of helping travelersmany of whom were confused or exhaustedthey seemed irritated and dismissive. I understand their job isnt easy, but a basic level of respect and professionalism should still be expected. This kind of experience leaves a very poor impression, especially for international visitors. I hope the airport authorities seriously look into improving the staffing, training, and overall management of the immigration area. Travelers deserve better.

TEXT: Extremely Poor Accessibility & Lack of Compassion I brought my elderly grandmotherwho requires a wheelchair and has dementiato the airport, and the accessibility experience was appalling. When I approached the front desk to request a wheelchair, I was told to go all the way to the check-in area at the end of the terminal first. How is someone supposed to leave a person with dementia alone while they go fetch a wheelchair? We had no choice but to walk the entire distance, which completely defeats the purpose of offering assistance in the first place. To make matters worse, the check-in counter we needed was right at the end of the row. If my grandmother had truly been immobile, she wouldve had no way to reach that point on her own. Imagine if she were a solo disabled travellerwhat would have happened then? Even more disappointing was the staff attitude. There were six front counter staff chatting among themselves, not a single smile, not a trace of compassion or initiative. It felt like basic empathy and responsibility were missing entirely. Accessibility should not be an afterthought, and neither should kindness.

We choice walk entire distance , completely defeat purpose offer assistance first place . To make matter bad , check-in counter need right end row . If grandmother truly immobile , wouldve way reach point . Imagine solo disable travellerwhat would happen ? Even disappointing staff attitude . There six front counter staff chat among , single smile , trace compassion initiative . It felt like basic empathy responsibility miss entirely . Accessibility afterthought , neither kindness .

TEXT: The immigration officers are rude and disrespectful. Not only do they seem uneducated, they are pretty disgusting in their treatment of travellers. Many Malays receive English education from elementary school but still can't speak English properly! How does that work? To be honest, it felt like the staff were completely uninterested in their job, and some even seemed to resent being there. If you don't want to be bullied, shouted at or ignored when asking questions during an already stressful flight trip, then avoid this airport at all cost! I was here on a 3 hour transit trip and within a span of those hours the amount of bullying and incompetence I observed was horrifying. Trust me this airport doesn't discriminate, nearly everyone of all nationalities and ethnicities feel the brunt of their hostility. Also, within 3 hours, the gate changed like 6 times! I have been to many major airports before, never faced something like this. What really stood out was the slogan displayed upon arrival: We hope youve enjoyed our Malaysian Hospitality. Frankly, this felt more like an empty promise than a reflection of the experience I had. A service should speak for itself, but in this case, it was clear that overcompensating with slogans only highlights the gap between what is advertised and what is actually delivered. Given this experience, I will never visit Malaysia again and I certainly won't be encouraging my friends or family to visit. Avoid countries that do not respect and appreciate tourist coming to help their economy!

TEXT: For such a major international hub, the airport felt a little confusing and chaotic. We ran into the same issue two times - once on arrival (for transit) and once for departure. During arrival we wanted to switch from C Gates to A/B gates for domestic departure but it was confusing to find the directions. Exactly at the same location, during departure, we had to switch to C gates but got confused. We later realised that one of the sign boards is actually wrong. It points to an escalator upwards that goes into the shopping area. Whereas the C gates entry is exactly in the opposite direction of the sign. For an international airport this is not acceptable at all. I dont have photos, but getting confused at the same place two times is not right. We saw a few others get confused too. Apart from that there is no major security check and body scan before immigration. However this is done prior to boarding. This is not as per standard processes elsewhere wherein the detailed security check and body scan is done immediately at entry. Somehow disappointed with the airport.

We saw others get confuse . Apart major security check body scan immigration . However do prior board . This per standard process elsewhere wherein detailed security check body scan do immediately entry . Somehow disappointed .

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always stood out for its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, is a beautiful highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of foreign and unique local offerings. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its due- the new bathrooms are a massive improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But I cant ignore the disappointing shift in retail and dining options. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. Also why is alcohol and tobacco taking up a large portion of the retail space every time? I was shocked to find only one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a foodie havenwhy isnt KLIA showcasing its rich culinary heritage and diversity? This seem to now be engulfed by the blandness of foreign cafe franchises, croissants and cakes. Would be delightful to have more local options! Gone are the great local options that once served authentic dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles and teh tarik. Instead, global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans dominate the F&B spaces. Surely, theres room for more homegrown eateries that represent Malaysias incredible food culture? To add to the frustration, the monorail is still not working, and travelers have to rely on shuttle buses- slow and less efficient. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phonecustomer service should be better than this. KLIA, we can do better! Support local businesses and bring back the true Malaysian experience.
processed_text: Ive travel KLIA countless time year , always stand cleanliness , smooth check-in process , efficient security check . The architecture , inspire Malaysian , Islamic , natural element , beautiful highlight . But truly make KLIA special balance foreign unique local offering . With recent KLIA1 renovation , I give credit due- new bathroom massive improvement ! Well-designed , clean , dry . But I cant ignore disappointing shift retail din option . Many local option disappear , replace foreign good . Also alcohol tobacco take large portion retail space every time ? I shock find one shelf Malaysian food product entire terminal 1 . Malaysia foodie havenwhy isnt KLIA showcasing rich culinary heritage diversity ? This seem engulf blandness foreign cafe franchise , croissant cake . Would delightful local option ! Gone great local option serve authentic dish like kaya toast , prawn noodle teh tarik . Instead , global chain like Starbucks Gloria Jeans dominate F & B space . Surely , there room homegrown eatery represent Malaysias incredible food culture ? To add frustration , monorail still work , traveler rely shuttle buses- slow less efficient . And I ask Ask Me For Help staff member food recommendation , barely look phonecustomer service good . KLIA , good ! Support local business bring back true Malaysian experience .

TEXT: KLIA2 is by far the most disappointing terminal, starting with the immigration service, which completely kills any desire to ever return here. Weve been to Malaysia many times, arriving through KLIA, but weve never seen such chaos. Over 300 people in line, and only 8 counters open - and working incredibly slowly! We waited in line for 1.5 (!) hours. Whats the point of filling out the online arrival form if immigration officers still spend 4-7 minutes on each tourist? After standing in line for over 1.5 hours and watching how the officers worked, we were left very disappointed. Even worse was how immigration officers treated Asian travelers with darker skin - their gestures were so disrespectful, it was truly unpleasant to witness.

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Although the airport was large and packed with lots of shops and eateries, there are areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving/departure passengers. Personally, I wasnt expecting to go through the hassle of having to transit from the plane to the arrival hall, taking into consideration that this was a direct flight. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member, who was shouting, to proceed to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall. This information could easily be missed if people are talking or focused on finding the nearest toilet. I tried to console myself, thinking that perhaps our flight was scheduled to park in a further lot due to multiple flights arriving around the same time. Anyway, just go with the flow and follow those in front since we are told to .... Would suggest the following improvements: * Rather than having a staff member shout instructions, you can consider placing clear, large signage on both sides of the walkway as passengers disembark. * Provide more readily available information upon flight arrival / departure. * Consider adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Clear directional signs and information would make a big difference for first-time visitors like myself and would save a lot of time especially when you have so many incoming/outgoing flights day to day..... The signage for the bus transfer was unclear, and it took approximately 4-5 minutes to find the waiting point to queue for the feeder bus to the arrival hall. Upon arriving at the arrival hall, it was another 2-minute walk to reach immigration. The area was extremely crowded, with queues of 2-3 lines in a row, resulting in an hour-long wait to clear immigration. The process was very disorganized and messy, with no one managing the human traffic, possibly due to a shortage of manpower. Although the officers were friendly and efficient in clearing the queue, it would be beneficial to have crowd control/security to guide and manage the flow of passengers. Locating the correct baggage belt after clearing immigration was another challenge. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts, requiring passengers to walk near the belt to check the monitor screen. This was frustrating, especially with different groups of people surrounding the area, some looking for directions, some waiting for friends, and others searching for the right belt. We eventually found our luggage placed not far away from the luggage belt area near the exit, with a sign displaying the SQ Airlines logo on the floor. Many unclaimed bags from our flight were present, as most passengers were still stuck in immigration. The entire process, from disembarking the plane to retrieving our luggage outside the baggage claim area, was challenging. I thought we were only required to transit to the arrival hall as a one-time occurrence. However, on our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient. As a tourist, the airport gives the first impression for passengers, and its organization is crucial. I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its duethe new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail spacewhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradisewhy isnt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign caf chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti? Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysias rich culinary diversity?- take a page out of Jakarta or Singapore airport. To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (Ive lost count how long Ive waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone. Customer service should be better than this! KLIA, lets do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers. P.S. if youre ever at the Satellite building of KLIA terminal 1, I highly recommend checking out the Jungle Boardwalk I always look forward to visiting it if my Gate is located there.

With recent KLIA1 renovation , I give credit duethe new bathroom huge improvement ! Well-designed , clean , dry . But retail din experience take disappointing turn . Many local option disappear , replace foreign good . And , alcohol tobacco seem dominate retail spacewhy much ? I shock find one shelf Malaysian food product entire terminal 1 . Malaysia food paradisewhy isnt KLIA celebrate ? Instead , vibrancy local flavor replace bland sameness foreign caf chain , croissant , cake . Surely , KLIA good make space homegrown eatery showcase Malaysias rich culinary diversity ? - take page Jakarta Singapore . To add frustration , monorail still service ( Ive lose count long Ive wait ) , force traveler rely slow inefficient shuttle bus . TEXT: The airport is huge. From Airline 1, you need to take a shuttle bus to Airline 2, but the bus goes incredibly fast and there are no handrails, so be careful. We were stuck in the line with the human linemen when we went through customs, so we had to wait in the line again when we returned home. Unfortunately, the human linemen were incredibly slow and inattentive, so the wait was incredibly long. So, we had to go through the machine at customs. It was also very crowded when we went inside to eat. I thought fast food would be faster, but the line at Burger King, ordering and picking up, can take an hour. It's not even fast food!? In the end, we didn't have time to eat and had to take it to go. There wasn't a single store in the airport that we could explore. The inspection process here is also very unique. You can bring water through the first checkpoint, but you have to go through the X-ray machine again before boarding the plane. You can't bring water this time. You're directly on the plane. There's no place to fill up your water or use the vending machines. My throat was really sore before the in-flight meal arrived. If you want to enjoy a leisurely stroll and eat, it's recommended to arrive 3-5 hours early. We arrived 3 hours early and were still in such a mess.

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its due- the new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well designed, good ventilation, clean and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail spacewhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradisewhy isnt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign coffe chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti? Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysias rich culinary diversity?- take a page out of Jakarta or Singapore airport. To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (Ive lost count how long Ive waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone as she was too busy texting her friend to care. Customer service should be better than this! KLIA, lets do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers. P.S. if youre ever at the Satellite building of KLIA terminal 1 (after the shuttle service), I highly recommend visiting the Jungle Boardwalk - a small beautiful green forest in the middle of the building I always look forward to visiting it if my Gate is located there.
processed_text: Ive travel KLIA countless time , always impress cleanliness , smooth check-in process , efficient security check . The architecture , inspire Malaysian , Islamic , natural element , remain stunning highlight . But truly make KLIA special balance international uniquely local offerings- something seem fade . With recent KLIA1 renovation , I give credit due- new bathroom huge improvement ! Well design , good ventilation , clean dry . But retail din experience take disappointing turn . Many local option disappear , replace foreign good . And , alcohol tobacco seem dominate retail spacewhy much ? I shock find one shelf Malaysian food product entire terminal 1 . Malaysia food paradisewhy isnt KLIA celebrate ? Instead , vibrancy local flavor replace bland sameness foreign coffe chain , croissant , cake . More AUTHENTIC local option would delight ! - especially leave home crave one last nasi lemak kuey teow teh tarik curry roti ? Once , traveler could enjoy authentic Malaysian dish like kaya toast , prawn noodle , teh tarik . Now , F & B scene overrun global chain like Starbucks Gloria Jeans . Surely , KLIA good make space homegrown eatery showcase Malaysias rich culinary diversity ? - take page Jakarta Singapore . To add frustration , monorail still service ( Ive lose count long Ive wait ) , force traveler rely slow inefficient shuttle bus . And I ask Ask Me For Help staff member food recommendation , barely look phone busy texting friend care . Customer service good ! KLIA , let good ! Support local business bring back authentic Malaysian experience traveller . P.S . youre ever Satellite building KLIA terminal 1 ( shuttle service ) , I highly recommend visit Jungle Boardwalk - small beautiful green forest middle building I always look forward visit Gate locate .

TEXT: There are many things to improve at this airport. There are twice as many security checks, passport checks, and boarding passes as at a Western airport. Just to give an example, the security process (where they check your water and all that) is right in front of the boarding gate. This means that once you've passed through security, you can't buy anything, including the toilet, water, etc. Aside from the inconvenience for travelers, it means underutilization of the machines for the airport, because they're only used when there's a flight at that gate, and fewer sales opportunities, because you're confined to that room for at least an hour and a half before the flight departs, waiting to actually board. They have a lot to learn from their neighbors in Singapore, a little further south.

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, "because it's too late now to buy tickets" (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid almost triple the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. Oh and did I mention that the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration? I had such a hard time to book the Grab and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, because there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!! This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

TEXT: I'm giving it 1 star for the following reasons: T1-> the security check only takes place immediately before boarding. This means that if you buy drinks before then (which you take with you on long-haul flights), you have to return them! Which is completely pointless! Furthermore, there's nothing to eat after baggage drop-off and passport control (which you want to get through as quickly as possible). Furthermore, there are no restrooms after the security check, so you'll wait about an hour for boarding plus a good 45 minutes until you're in the air to use a restroom... I've never seen anything like it, and I've been to many countries/continents.

TEXT: Edit: upon arrival as of June 2025, they removed auto entry now for foreign passports and only locals can go through them- what a waste of automated gates! KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, its still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights. On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tediousyoure required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but theres little travelers can do about it. Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

Shops dining option still quite limited despite 's large size , bit disappointing traveler look explore relax flight . On positive side , certain passport holder , biometric scanning immigration make process quick efficient , welcome convenience . However , baggage scan process remain tediousyoure require scan bag multiple time , enter immigration head gate . Personally , feel unnecessarily repetitive , theres little traveler . TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) in Malaysia is a major aviation hub known for its modern infrastructure and significant passenger capacity. It features two main terminals: KLIA1 (Main Terminal) for full-service airlines and KLIA2, which is the worlds largest terminal dedicated to low-cost carriers. Both terminals provide extensive amenities such as check-in counters, retail outlets, duty-free shops, lounges, and a range of dining options. Despite its impressive size and facilities, passenger experiences at KLIA show a mixed picture. Some travelers appreciate the airports efficiency, particularly with business class services that offer quick access to lounges and smooth security checks. The connectivity is good, with efficient transportation options like the KLIA Ekspres train linking the airport to Kuala Lumpur city center in under 30 minutes, plus taxis and buses are readily available. However, there are notable complaints that affect the overall impression. Passengers frequently cite poor staff behavior, long queues, and confusion during boarding and baggage checks, often describing staff as unfriendly or inattentive. Some criticize the immigration process, mentioning inconvenient requirements and poor assistance, especially for transit passengers. Food and beverage options, particularly in KLIA2, have received negative reviews for being limited, expensive, or insufficient for the passenger volume. Seating areas can be inadequate during peak times, and the indoor climate control sometimes falls short, making waiting uncomfortable. In terms of infrastructure, KLIA offers modern and clean facilities, with well-organized terminals and a spacious layout. The addition of automated train systems within KLIA1 and a skybridge in KLIA2 has improved passenger movement. The airport continues to be recognized for service quality by industry bodies, but in practice, staff performance and customer service remain areas needing improvement. Overall, KLIA is a modern and strategically important airport that provides extensive amenities and connectivity but is let down by inconsistent service quality and operational challenges that impact traveler satisfaction.Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) in Malaysia is a major and modern airport serving millions yearly, with two main terminals: KLIA1 for full-service airlines and KLIA2 dedicated to budget carriers. Both terminals feature extensive amenities including retail outlets, duty-free shops, lounges, and various dining options, supported by advanced infrastructure like automated trains and skybridges for smooth passenger transfers. While the airport excels in its size, facilities, and connectivityoffering quick transportation options like the KLIA Ekspres train to Kuala Lumpurit has garnered mixed overall reviews from travelers. Many praise KLIA1 for efficient and smooth security and boarding processes, especially for business class passengers. However, there are widespread complaints about staff attitude, with reports of unfriendly and inattentive personnel, chaotic queues, and confusing procedures that dampen the experience. Other common issues include limited food and beverage options, especially in KLIA2, overcrowded seating areas, and inconsistent indoor climate control, making waiting uncomfortable during peak times. Some travelers also find the immigration and transfer processes cumbersome, with poor assistance and odd paperwork requirements for transit passengers. Despite these challenges, KLIA maintains a clean and modern terminal environment with generally well-maintained facilities. It has received industry awards for its infrastructure and immigration service, but passenger experiences suggest that improving customer service and operational management is needed to match the airports world-class status. In summary, KLIA offers comprehensive facilities and good connectivity as Malaysias primary international gateway but is hampered by service inconsistencies and operational issues that impact passenger satisfaction.

TEXT: I used Terminal 2 (KLIA2), which is mainly used by low-cost carriers. There are many restaurants just outside the arrival gate, and many of them are open 24 hours a day, which is very convenient. There are many seats where you can charge your phones, and some stores have Wi-Fi. The food court a little further back to the left of the arrival gate has very cheap prices. The supermarket called JayaGROCER is also cheap. When you arrive, you can get to the city center by taking the KLIA Express, a limited express train, which is cheap and fast. However, there are restrictions on departure times, so if you want to get around easily, you should use the car dispatch service "Grab" or a taxi. The cheapest option is by far the bus. There is a luxurious lounge that accepts Priority Pass (3-hour system) at the back of LEVEL3, where the boarding gate is located, to the left. I saw a few people sleeping on the ground on the boarding gate floor at night. However, the downside is that it is a very long walk to the boarding gate. After the initial simple baggage inspection, it takes about 20 minutes to walk to the gate.

When arrive , get city center take KLIA Express , limited express train , cheap fast . However , restriction departure time , want get around easily , use car dispatch service `` Grab '' taxi . TEXT: Edit: upon arrival, they removed auto entry now for foreign passports and only locals can go through them- what a waste of automated gates! KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, its still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights. On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tediousyoure required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but theres little travelers can do about it. Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport, also known as KLIA. In addition to the main airport building, there's a separate, cross-shaped airport building for arrivals and boarding. If you use this building for departures and arrivals, you'll need to take the free shuttle train for immigration and boarding. For Koreans, this system is similar to Incheon International Airport. You can purchase and board the KLIA Express, a popular option for travel into Kuala Lumpur. Be sure to prepare your MDAC (Malaysian Declaration of Arrival) in advance. The facilities are clean and there are plenty of duty-free shops.

TEXT: It is the largest airport in Malaysia and one of the busiest airports in Asia. The airport was built at a cost of up to 3.5 billion USD and was inaugurated on June 27, 1998. Japanese architect Kisho Kurokawa designed this airport. The airport is 50 km from the capital Kuala Lumpur. In 2009, this airport served 29.6 million passengers (lower than the expected 35 million passengers). This airport has a 130 m high air traffic control tower, the second highest among air traffic control towers (only after the tower at Suvarnabhumi International Airport in Bangkok) with 2 runways 60 m wide and more than 4,000 m long, capable of serving 120 flights/hour. According to the plan, this airport will have 4 runways. Terminal capacity in phase 2 to 2012 is 35 million passengers/year and in phase 2 to 2012 is 45 million passengers/year. #KuaLaLumPurAirport

This 130 high air traffic control tower , second high among air traffic control tower ( tower Suvarnabhumi International Airport Bangkok ) 2 runway 60 wide 4,000 long , capable serve 120 flights/hour . According plan , 4 runway . Terminal capacity phase 2 2012 35 million passengers/year phase 2 2012 45 million passengers/year . # KuaLaLumPurAirport

TEXT: Airport Terminal 1 boasts modern upgrades to its luggage drop, check-in, immigration processes, and overall size. It is located approximately 60 minutes from Kuala Lumpur by car, or a quicker 45-minute journey via express train. However, there are a few areas for potential improvement. 1. Currently, there is a lack of a dedicated food court. While some cafes and pantries offer refreshments, the options are limited to cold food, and the only Burger King and other food options are situated at Gate C, inconveniently distant from other gates. The travel time to Gate C from other gates is 15 minutes one-way by bus. 2. Seating is somewhat limited. 3. Entertainment options for children and families could be expanded. 4. The washrooms could be enhanced by providing tissue paper in the hand-wash areas. 5. Duty-free prices may be considered slightly higher than in some other countries. The airport does offer complimentary Wi-Fi access for all passengers and provides adequate restroom facilities.

TEXT: This is Kuala Lumpur International Airport. There is free Wi-Fi at the airport, so if you haven't purchased a SIM card yet, please use the free Wi-Fi at the airport first. The airport here is designed a little differently, with departure and arrival terminals connected. I was arriving that day, but following the directions, I passed the departure lobby and duty-free shops and went to immigration. I was then directed to C5, and took a bus to the arrival immigration. If you don't know the way, it's easy to get lost, so if you get lost, be sure to ask a nearby staff member for directions right away. The airport itself is large, so it took about 40 minutes from arrival to baggage claim. It's about an hour's drive from here to Kuala Lumpur city. Malaysia is a fusion of various cultures, including Chinese, Islamic, and Buddhist.

TEXT: The airport is very large. Arrivals on a Tuesday evening were relatively smooth. Famous restaurants like Hua Yang and Hai Jiao Ren are located at the airport. I highly recommend checking them out first, as the lines at restaurants downtown are incredibly long. Departures on Saturday morning were a bit more chaotic, with incredibly crowded people and numerous check-in counters. They weren't divided by flight. From previous travel experience, children can't check in at the check-in counter. So, initially, we kept looking for a human check-in counter. We asked three staff members, each with a different explanation. This wasted a lot of time. It just so happened that our flight was delayed by an hour, otherwise we might have missed it. The restaurant in the airport lobby was incredibly crowded. After finally getting a table, it took another 30 minutes. We later discovered there were still many shops and restaurants after customs. Furthermore, baggage screening at customs required two checks, and the distance from customs to the boarding gate was quite long. On the way back, I recommend exploring and eating at the gate. You don't have to crowd the outermost area; the restaurants inside are just like the airport lobby. Best of all, they were less crowded, allowing you to leisurely wait for your flight. We had some fast food recommended by a local. The cola looked like root beer, served from a machine that looked like draft beer. It was quite interesting. The pancakes were surprisingly deliciouslarge, crispy, and generously prepared.

TEXT: KLIA is a decent and well-maintained airport, with clear signages and good connectivity to the city via the KLIA Express. The airport offers a range of facilities, shopping, and dining options, and generally handles immigration and security procedures efficiently. However, compared to airports like Singapores Changi, I find KLIA lacks a certain warmth and polish. The overall design feels a bit dated, and some areas can be quite empty or underwhelming in terms of atmosphere. While functional, it doesnt offer the same level of comfort, innovation, or world-class amenities that Changi is known for. Still, for travel in and out of Malaysia, KLIA does its job well. Its just not my favorite airport in the region.

TEXT: The airport is clean. When you get off at Terminal 1, follow the arrivals signs and continue walking until you reach the terminal where you must take the elevator. You must take the elevator to get to the main terminal. There are many duty-free shops nearby. It might seem strange because it's different from Korea, but don't worry. Just keep going straight and take the elevator. Once you get off, go straight for a bit and then descend to the basement. You'll need to go down to the arrivals hall. The problem here is that the wait for immigration can sometimes exceed an hour. The line for complete immigration is incredibly long. You'll need to pass through here to collect your luggage and exit. It can be a little confusing, but just remember that you have to take the elevator, walk a bit, and then descend to the basement. Have a nice trip.

TEXT: Edit: upon arrival as of June 2025, they removed auto entry now for foreign passports and only locals can go through them- what a waste of automated gates! KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, its still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights. On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tediousyoure required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but theres little travelers can do about it. Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

On positive side , certain passport holder , biometric scanning immigration make process quick efficient , welcome convenience . However , baggage scan process remain tediousyoure require scan bag multiple time , enter immigration head gate . Personally , feel unnecessarily repetitive , theres little traveler . Overall , KLIA potential , hopefully , ongoing upgrade bring noticeable improvement facility passenger experience near future .

TEXT: Information for Turkish friends: After disembarking on August 7, 2025, it took us about an hour to get to the Grapla hotel. These procedures include going through passport control, collecting luggage, converting money, and going to Gate 5 on the lowest floor. When you arrive, you first fill out a form using a QR code. This information is sent to your email address. Then, when you go through passport control, you fill it out and you enter the country without any problems. I recommend getting training before you arrive. The airport's Wi-Fi works very well. It's very easy to get to the Grapla city center or your hotel. It's not very practical to exchange money at the airport. You can exchange $20 if you have a small amount of cash with you. Grapla is level 1, door 5.

TEXT: So first of all: the airport is big!!! The usual recommendation to be at the airport at least 3 hours before departure should be strictly adhered to. There are multiple floors and the terminal with Gates C is outside and requires an additional bus ride. Positive: There is a large selection of warm food and drinks in the Arrival Hall early in the morning. The Departure Hall is on the top floor and is very cluttered and full of people. It's important to stay calm and ask for the airline at the information counter. The signage at the counters is small and you would have to look through all of them until you find the right one. (If you fly with Etihad Airways... it's counter A.) It's best to check in online... it saves time. There were initially only a few counters open and some passengers had a lot of suitcases that were all weighed and labeled. The same thing happens with hand luggage. As soon as you have got rid of your checked baggage, it is best to go to immigration without hesitation and then you can stand in line again. TEXT: KLIA 1 Airport is quite big and beautiful, but the design is a bit old-fashioned. I got Gate C for International Departures and had to take another bus to get there because this airport is so big. Luckily the road signs are quite clear, and the bus also comes quickly. TEXT: KLIA has room for improvement in several areas. The air conditioning was not cold enough, making the airport feel quite stuffy. The water dispensers were not functioning, which was inconvenient for travelers looking to refill their bottles. Signage is another major issue, particularly for McDonald's. While there's a visible kiosk near Jamie Oliver, the other McDonald's outlet is poorly marked and easy to miss, hidden behind people and lacking clear directions. The KFC location is also not well-indicated, making it difficult for first-time visitors to find. On a positive note, the toilet cleanliness is commendable. The cleaning staff are diligent, ensuring the facilities are spotless after each use. This level of hygiene is definitely appreciated and sets a good standard for airport maintenance.

The KFC location also well-indicated , make difficult first-time visitor find . On positive note , toilet cleanliness commendable . The cleaning staff diligent , ensure facility spotless use . TEXT: Disappointed with KLIA1s Renovation Wheres the Local Flavor? Ive traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, easy check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, influenced by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, is a highlight. But what made KLIA truly special was the presence of local food, beverages, and products. With the recent renovation of KLIA1, I have to say I am very pleased with the new improved bathrooms- better designed, clean and dry :) But Ive noticed a disappointing shiftmany local offerings have been replaced by foreign goods, with alcohol and tobacco dominating the retail space. I was shocked to find only one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal! Malaysia is a foodie paradise with so much to offer- why isnt KLIA showcasing it? Previously, there were great local cafs serving authentic Malaysian dishes like prawn noodles and teh tarik. Now, all I see are global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans. Cant there be more homegrown F&B options for travelers to experience real Malaysian flavors? To top it off, the monorail is still not working (shuttle busses are the alternate) and my attempt to ask an Ask Me For Help staff member about food options was met with disinterestshe was too busy scrolling on her phone to assist me properly. KLIA, we can do better! Support local businesses and bring back the Malaysian experience!

With recent renovation KLIA1 , I say I pleased new improve bathrooms- well design , clean dry : ) But Ive notice disappointing shiftmany local offering replace foreign good , alcohol tobacco dominate retail space . TEXT: Airport Terminal 1 boasts modern upgrades to its luggage drop, check-in, immigration processes, and overall size. It's located approximately 60 minutes from Kuala Lumpur by car, or a quicker 45-minute journey via express train. However, there are a few areas for potential improvement. 1. Currently, there is a lack of a dedicated food court. While some cafes and pantries offer refreshments, the options are limited to cold food, and the only Burger King is situated at Gate C, inconveniently distant from other gates. 2. Seating is somewhat limited. 3. Entertainment options for children and families could be expanded. 4. The washrooms could be enhanced by providing tissue paper in the hand-wash areas. 5. Duty-free prices may be considered slightly higher than in some other countries. The airport does offer complimentary Wi-Fi access for all passengers and provides adequate restroom facilities.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport is generally fine, clean, and organized. My experience with the immigration officer was also nice, they were polite and professional. However, the immigration line was extremely long. We ended up waiting around 2 hours just to get through. It would be much better if they had autogates available for all international visitors, not just for selected countries. That would save so much time and make the arrival process smoother. Overall, the airport itself is good, but the long wait at immigration was really exhausting.

TEXT: Edit: upon arrival, they removed auto entry now for foreign passports and only locals can go through them- what a waste of automated gates! KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, its still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights. On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tediousyoure required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but theres little travelers can do about it. Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

However , baggage scan process remain tediousyoure require scan bag multiple time , enter immigration head gate . Personally , feel unnecessarily repetitive , theres little traveler . Overall , KLIA potential , hopefully , ongoing upgrade bring noticeable improvement facility passenger experience near future .

TEXT: Malaysia will celebrate Merdeka Day at the end of August 2025. The airspace around KLIA (Kuala Lumpur International Airport) will be temporarily closed from 8:00 AM to 12:00 PM daily from August 26th to 31st. Flights departing or arriving during this period may be adjusted! To this end, Malaysia Airlines has announced on its website that departure and arrival times for certain flights will be adjusted. For details on affected flights, please visit their website; I've only captured a partial screenshot! I think other airlines will be affected to some extent, so please check in advance Malaysia will celebrate Merdeka's Independence Day at the end of August, and the airspace around KLIA (Kuala Lumpur International Airport) will be temporarily closed from 8 am to 12 noon every day from 8.26 to 8.31. The small partners who leave/arrive during this time, the flight may be adjusted! To this end, Malaysia Airlines has indicated in official website that the departure and arrival times of the corresponding flights will be adjusted. You can go to their official website to check the specific flight tips, and I only took a partial screenshot! ! ! I think other airlines will be affected to some extent. Please confirm in advance.

TEXT: Large international airport. Two Terminals 1 &2. For newcomers, need to have more signals and instructions. But the process was still smooth. It could be faster if more clear instructions. Many eateries and souvenir shops. Have free water dispenser at the boarding gate after security check. The custom was very nice. For Arrival: Singapore Airlines, from Singapore, arrived at Gate C. Gate C zone -> Aerotrain every 10 minutes (~ 4-5 staff there) to Immigration counter/ Gate ABGH -> Many long queues for foreign passport holder, and prepare MDAC (Malaysia Digital Arrival Card) -> Luggage claim-> simple luggage X-rays Check -> leave Airport restricted area -> buy SIM cards / money exchange -> transportation. For Departure: Singapore Airlines to Singapore. Immigration e-channel or Counters (special Counter for business/first class) -> security check -> Aerotrain to Gate C -> (Lounge/ Eat/shopping) -> security check to enter the assigned boarding gate.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is more than just a travel hub its a complete experience that blends efficiency, comfort, and a touch of Malaysian hospitality. From the moment you arrive, the design of the airport stands out. The main terminal building is bright, spacious, and airy, with a modern architectural style that still feels warm and welcoming. The satellite building, connected by the Aerotrain, adds to the sense of scale and convenience, making it easy for passengers to transfer between terminals. In terms of navigation, KLIA is well signposted, with clear directions in English and Malay. Even for first-time visitors, its relatively simple to find immigration, baggage claim, and onward connections. While the airport is large, the layout is intuitive, and staff members are friendly and ready to assist if you ever feel lost. Immigration and security checks are usually smooth and efficient, although during peak travel hours there can be queues nothing unusual for an airport of this size. The facilities here are excellent. There is a wide variety of food and drink options catering to every budget, from local Malaysian dishes (which I highly recommend if you have time) to international fast food, coffee shops, and sit-down restaurants. Shopping is also a highlight the duty-free selection is extensive, with everything from cosmetics and electronics to Malaysian souvenirs and delicacies. If youre in transit or have a long layover, KLIA makes the wait comfortable. There are plenty of lounges, seating areas, and even a capsule hotel where you can book a few hours of rest. The airport also has prayer rooms, child-friendly facilities, and smoking zones, which shows that it caters thoughtfully to different types of travelers. Free Wi-Fi is available, though it can sometimes be a little slow, so its good to have mobile data as backup. Getting to and from the airport is extremely convenient. The KLIA Ekspres train is one of the best features it takes just under 30 minutes to reach KL Sentral in the city center, and its fast, comfortable, and reliable. Taxis and ride-hailing services are also widely available, and buses provide budget-friendly options. One thing to keep in mind is that the airport is quite large, so be prepared to walk a fair bit between gates or from security to boarding. For some travelers, this can be tiring, but the clear signage and moving walkways help a lot. Overall, KLIA is a world-class airport that balances efficiency with comfort. Its clean, modern, and well-maintained, but it also has a distinct cultural touch that reminds you youre in Malaysia. Whether youre arriving, departing, or transiting, KLIA leaves a positive impression and sets the tone for a great journey.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KUL) is a major international airport serving Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Here are some key points about the airport: Airport Information - *Location:* Kuala Lumpur International Airport is located about 45 kilometers south of Kuala Lumpur city center. - *Terminals:* The airport has multiple terminals, including Terminal 1, Terminal 2, and the KLIA2 terminal for low-cost carriers. Amenities and Services - *Dining:* The airport offers a wide range of dining options, including restaurants, cafes, and snack bars. - *Shopping:* There are various shops selling duty-free products, souvenirs, and other items. - *Currency Exchange:* Currency exchange services are available at the airport. - *Transportation:* The airport offers various transportation options, including taxis, buses, trains, and car rentals. Airlines and Destinations - *Malaysia Airlines:* Kuala Lumpur International Airport is the hub for Malaysia Airlines. - *International Flights:* The airport offers flights to various international destinations in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and Oceania. Tips for Travelers - *Plan Ahead:* Arrive at the airport with plenty of time to spare before your flight. - *Check Flight Status:* Check the status of your flight before heading to the airport. - *Know the Airport Layout:* Familiarize yourself with the airport's layout to make the most of your time.
